increased aggressiveness.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Golub Mari S. |author2=Hogrefe Casey E. |author3=Unger Erica L. | year = 2012 | title = Influence of prenatal iron deficiency and MAOA genotype on response to social challenge in rhesus monkey infants | url = | journal = Genes, Brain and Behavior | volume = 11 | issue = 3| pages = 278–290 | doi=10.1111/j.1601-183x.2012.00772.x|pmc=3511847 | pmid=22340208}}</ref> Inexpensive and effective iron supplementation is an available preventative strategy recommended by the World Health Organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/nutrition/publications/micronutrients/guidelines/daily_ifa_supp_pregnant_women/en/|title=WHO - Archived: Daily iron and folic acid supplementation in pregnant women|website=WHO}}</ref> However, iron supplementation can exacerbate malaria infection. Therefore, individuals receiving iron supplementation in malaria-endemic areas must be carefully monitored.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Ojukwu J. U. |author2=Okebe J. U. |author3=Yahav D. |author4=Paul M. | year = 2010 | title = Cochrane review: Oral iron supplementation for preventing or treating anaemia among children in malaria‐endemic areas | url = | journal = Evidence-Based Child Health: A Cochrane Review Journal | volume = 5 | issue = 2| pages = 967–1183 | doi=10.1002/ebch.542}}</ref>
===Zinc=== Zinc is essential for the structure and function of thousands of proteins critical for the function of every cell.<ref>{{cite book |first1=Wolfgang|last1=Maret|editor1-first=Lucia (Ed.) |editor1-last=Banci |series=Metal Ions in Life Sciences |volume=12|chapter= Chapter 14 Zinc and the Zinc Proteome |title=Metallomics and the Cell |year=2013 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-94-007-5560-4|doi=10.1007/978-94-007-5561-10_14}} electronic-book {{ISBN|978-94-007-5561-1}} {{issn|1559-0836}} electronic-{{issn|1868-0402}} </ref> Zinc can also serve as a neurotransmitter in the brain,<ref>{{cite journal | author = Saadi R. A., He K., Hartnett K. A., Kandler K., Hershfinkel M., Aizenman E. | year = 2012 | title = SNARE-dependent upregulation of potassium chloride co-transporter 2 activity after metabotropic zinc receptor activation in rat cortical neurons'' in vitro'' | url = | journal = Neuroscience | volume = 210 | issue = | pages = 38–46 | pmid = 22441041 | last2 = He | last3 = Hartnett | last4 = Kandler | last5 = Hershfinkel | last6 = Aizenman | doi = 10.1016/j.neuroscience.2012.03.001 | pmc = 3358579 }}</ref> thus a deficiency of this mineral can clearly disrupt development as well as neurophysiology. For example, zinc deficiency during early development impairs neurogenesis leading to memory impairments.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Dvergsten C. L. |author2=Johnson L. A. |author3=Sandstead H. H. | year = 1984 | title = Alterations in the postnatal development of the cerebellar cortex due to zinc deficiency. III. Impaired dendritic differentiation of basket and stellate cells | url = | journal = Developmental Brain Research | volume = 16 | issue = 1| pages = 21–26 | doi=10.1016/0165-3806(84)90058-0}}</ref><ref name="Nuttall, J. R. 2012">{{cite journal |author1=Nuttall J. R. |author2=Oteiza P. I. | year = 2012 | title = Zinc and the ERK kinases in the developing brain | url = | journal = Neurotoxicity Research | volume = 21 | issue = 1| pages = 128–141 | doi=10.1007/s12640-011-9291-6 | pmid=22095091| pmc=4316815}}</ref> However, zinc deficiency later in life can disrupt appetite and cause depression like behavior.<ref name="Nuttall, J. R. 2012"/><ref>{{cite journal | author = Tassabehji N. M., Corniola R. S., Alshingiti A., Levenson C. W. | year = 2008 | title = Zinc deficiency induces depression-like symptoms in adult rats | url = | journal = Physiology & Behavior | volume = 95 | issue = 3| pages = 365–369 | doi=10.1016/j.physbeh.2008.06.017| last2 = Corniola | last3 = Alshingiti | last4 = Levenson }}</ref> However, it is important to consider copper intake relative to zinc supplementation because excess zinc can disrupt copper absorption.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Doherty K., Connor M., Cruickshank R. | year = 2011 | title = Zinc-containing denture adhesive: a potential source of excess zinc resulting in copper deficiency myelopathy | url = | journal = British Dental Journal | volume = 210 | issue = 11| pages = 523–525 | pmid = 21660014 | last2 = Connor | last3 = Cruickshank | doi = 10.1038/sj.bdj.2011.428 }}</ref>
====Deficiency==== Conservative estimates suggest that 25% of the world's population is at risk of zinc deficiency.<ref name="pmid16632171">{{cite journal |author=Maret W, Sandstead HH |title=Zinc requirements and the risks and benefits of zinc supplementation |journal=J Trace Elem Med Biol |volume=20 |issue=1 |pages=3–18 |year=2006 |pmid=16632171 |doi=10.1016/j.jtemb.2006.01.006|last2=Sandstead }}</ref>
Hypozincemia is usually a nutritional deficiency, but can also be associated with [[malabsorption]], [[diarrhea]], [[acrodermatitis enteropathica]], [[Chronic (medicine)|chronic]] [[liver disease]], chronic [[renal disease]], [[sickle-cell disease]], [[diabetes]], [[malignancy]], pyroluria, and other chronic [[illness]]es.<ref>{{Cite GPnotebook|886046736|zinc deficiency}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Prasad AS |title=Zinc deficiency : Has been known of for 40 years but ignored by global health organisations |journal=BMJ |volume=326 |issue=7386 |pages=409–10 |year=2003 |pmid=12595353 |pmc=1125304 |doi=10.1136/bmj.326.7386.409 |url=http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/326/7386/409}}</ref> It can also occur after [[bariatric surgery]], heavy metal exposure<ref>{{cite journal |author1=El-Safty Ibrahim A M |author2=Gadallah Mohsen |author3=Shafik Ahmed |author4=Shouman Ahmed E | year = 2002 | title = Effect of mercury vapour exposure on urinary excretion of calcium, zinc and copper: relationship to alterations in functional and structural integrity of the kidney | url = | journal = Toxicol Ind Health | volume = 18 | issue = 8| pages = 377–388 | pmid = 15119526 | doi=10.1191/0748233702th160oa}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Funk Day, Brady | year = 1987 | title = Displacement of zinc and copper from copper-induced metallothionein by cadmium and by mercury: in vivo and ex vivo studies | url = | journal = Comp Biochem Physiol C | volume = 86 | issue = 1| pages = 1–6 | pmid = 2881702 | doi=10.1016/0742-8413(87)90133-2}}</ref> and tartrazine. {{Citation needed|date=March 2013}}
Zinc deficiency is typically the result of inadequate dietary intake of zinc, disease states that promote zinc losses, or physiological states that require increased zinc. Populations that consume primarily plant based diets that are low in bioavailable zinc often have zinc deficiencies.<ref>Solomons, N.W. (2001) Dietary Sources of zinc and factors affecting its bioavailability. Food Nutr. Bull. 22: 138-154</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Sandstead HH |title=Zinc deficiency. A public health problem? |journal=Am. J. Dis. Child. |volume=145 |issue=8 |pages=853–9 |year=1991 |pmid=1858720 |doi= 10.1001/archpedi.1991.02160080029016|url=}}</ref> Diseases or conditions that involve intestinal malabsorption promote zinc losses. Fecal losses of zinc caused by diarrhea are one contributing factor,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Castillo-Duran C, Vial P, Uauy R |title=Trace mineral balance during acute diarrhea in infants |journal=J. Pediatr. |volume=113 |issue=3 |pages=452–7 |year=1988 |pmid=3411389 |doi= 10.1016/S0022-3476(88)80627-9|url=|last2=Vial |last3=Uauy }}</ref> often common in [[developing countries]]. Changes in intestinal tract absorbability and permeability due, in part, to viral, protozoal, and bacteria pathogens may also encourage fecal losses of zinc.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Manary MJ |title=Dietary phytate reduction improves zinc absorption in Malawian children recovering from tuberculosis but not in well children |journal=J. Nutr. |volume=130 |issue=12 |pages=2959–64 |year=2000 |pmid=11110854 |doi= |url=http://jn.nutrition.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11110854 |name-list-format=vanc|author2=Hotz C |author3=Krebs NF |display-authors=3 |last4=Gibson |first4=RS |last5=Westcott |first5=JE |last6=Arnold |first6=T |last7=Broadhead |first7=RL |last8=Hambidge |first8=KM}}</ref> Physiological states that require increased zinc include periods of growth in infants and children as well as in mothers during pregnancy.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Gibson RS |title=Zinc: the missing link in combating micronutrient malnutrition in developing countries |journal=Proc Nutr Soc |volume=65 |issue=1 |pages=51–60 |year=2006 |pmid=16441944 |doi= 10.1079/PNS2005474|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/abstract_S0029665106000073}}</ref>
=====Anorexia===== {{Main|Anorexia (symptom)}}
Zinc deficiency may cause a decrease in [[appetite]] which can degenerate into [[anorexia (symptom)|anorexia]] or [[anorexia nervosa]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21846317 | volume=3 | issue=3 | title=Zinc as an appetite stimulator - the possible role of zinc in the progression of diseases such as cachexia and sarcopenia | journal=Recent Patents on Food, Nutrition & Agriculture |date=September 2011 | author=Suzuki H, Asakawa A, Li JB | pages=226–31 | doi=10.2174/2212798411103030226| author2=and others | displayauthors=1 | last3=Li | last4=Tsai | last5=Amitani | last6=Ohinata | last7=Komai | last8=Inui }}</ref> Appetite disorders, in turn, cause [[malnutrition]] and, notably, inadequate zinc intake. Anorexia itself is a cause of zinc deficiency, thus leading to a vicious cycle: the worsening of anorexia worsens the zinc deficiency. A 1994 randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial showed that zinc (14 mg per day) doubled the rate of body mass increase in the treatment of anorexia nervosa.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Birmingham C. L. |author2=Goldner E. M. |author3=Bakan R. | year = 1994 | title = Controlled trial of zinc supplementation in anorexia nervosa | doi = 10.1002/1098-108X(199404)15:3<251::AID-EAT2260150308>3.0.CO;2-# | journal = International Journal of Eating Disorders | volume = 15 | issue = 3| pages = 251–255 | pmid = 8199605 }}</ref>
=====Cognitive and motor function impairment===== Cognitive and motor function may also be impaired in zinc deficient children. Zinc deficiency can interfere with many organ systems especially when it occurs during a time of rapid growth and development when nutritional needs are high, such as during infancy.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Sanstead H. H. | year = 2000 | title = Zinc nutriture as related to brain | url = | journal = J. Nutr. | volume = 130 | issue = | pages = 140S–146S | displayauthors = etal }}</ref> In [[animal studies]], rats who were deprived of zinc during early fetal development exhibited increased emotionality, poor memory, and abnormal response to stress which interfered with performance in learning situations.<ref name="MM">{{cite journal |author=Black MM |title=The Evidence Linking Zinc Deficiency with Children's Cognitive and Motor Functioning, |journal=J. Nutr. |volume=133 |issue=5 Suppl 1 |pages=1473S–6S |year=2003 |pmid=12730446 |doi= |url=http://jn.nutrition.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12730446 |pmc=3137935}}</ref> Zinc deprivation in monkeys showed that zinc deficient animals were emotionally less mature, and also had cognitive deficits indicated by their difficulty in retaining previously learned problems and in learning new problems.<ref name="MM"/> Human observational studies show weaker results. Low maternal zinc status has been associated with less attention during the neonatal period and worse motor functioning.<ref name="Black">{{cite journal |author=Black MM |title=Zinc deficiency and child development |journal=Am. J. Clin. Nutr. |volume=68 |issue=2 Suppl |pages=464S–9S |year=1998 |pmid=9701161 |doi= |url=http://www.ajcn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=9701161 |pmc=3137936}}</ref> In some studies, supplementation has been associated with motor development in very low [[birth weight]] infants and more vigorous and functional activity in infants and toddlers.<ref name="Black" />
Plasma zinc level has been associated with many psychological disorders. However, the nature of this relationship remains unclear in most instances. An increasing amount of evidence suggests that zinc deficiency could play a causal role in the etiology of depression.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nuttall|first=J|author2=Oteiza |title=Zinc and the ERK kinases in the developing brain|journal=Neurotoxicity Research|year=2012|volume=21|issue=1|pages=128–141|doi=10.1007/s12640-011-9291-6|pmid=22095091|pmc=4316815}}</ref> Indeed, zinc supplementation has been reported to improve measures of depression in randomized double blind placebo controlled trials.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=20087376 | doi=10.1038/ejcn.2009.158 | volume=64 | issue=3 | title=Effect of zinc supplementation on mood states in young women: a pilot study |date=March 2010 | author=Sawada T, Yokoi K | journal=Eur J Clin Nutr | pages=331–3| last2=Yokoi }}</ref>
===Copper=== Copper is important for the function of many enzymes in the brain. Notably, dopamine β-mono-oxygenase is affected by copper deficiency leading to increased dopamine and decreased norepinephrine levels.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Nelson K. T., Prohaska J. R. | year = 2009 | title = Copper deficiency in rodents alters dopamine b-mono-oxygenase activity, mRNA and protein level | url = | journal = British Journal of Nutrition | volume = 102 | issue = 1| pages = 18–28 | pmid = 19079842 | last2 = Prohaska | doi = 10.1017/S0007114508162961 }}</ref> Both copper deficiency and toxicity can interfere with brain development and function.
====Deficiency==== The neurodegenerative syndrome of copper deficiency has been recognized for some time in ruminant animals, in which it is commonly known as "[[swayback]]".<ref name="Jaiser, copper myelopathy" /> The disease involves a nutritional deficiency in the trace element [[copper]].<ref name="Jaiser, copper myelopathy">{{cite journal |author1=Jaiser S. R. |author2=Winston G. P. | year = 2010 | title = Copper deficiency myelopathy | url = | journal = Journal of Neurology | volume = 257 | issue = 6| pages = 869–881 | doi=10.1007/s00415-010-5511-x| pmc=3691478}}</ref> Copper is ubiquitous and daily requirement is low making acquired copper deficiency very rare. Copper deficiency can manifest in parallel with vitamin B12 and other nutritional deficiencies.<ref name="Half">{{cite journal |author1=Halfdanarson T. R. |author2=Kumar N. |author3=Li C. Y. |author4=Phyliky R. L. |author5=Hogan W. J. | year = 2008 | title = Hematological manifestations of copper deficiency: a retrospective review. [Article] | url = | journal = European Journal of Haematology | volume = 80 | issue = 6| pages = 523–531 | doi=10.1111/j.1600-0609.2008.01050.x}}</ref> The most common cause of copper deficiency is a remote gastrointestinal surgery, such as gastric bypass surgery, due to malabsorption of copper, or zinc toxicity. On the other hand, [[Menkes disease]] is a genetic disorder of copper deficiency involving a wide variety of symptoms that is often fatal.<ref name="Kodama">{{cite journal |author1=Kodama H. |author2=Fujisawa C. | year = 2009 | title = Copper metabolism and inherited copper transport disorders: molecular mechanisms, screening, and treatment | url = | journal = Metallomics | volume = 1 | issue = 1| pages = 42–52 | doi=10.1039/b816011m}}</ref>
=====Neurological presentation===== Copper deficiency can cause a wide variety of neurological problems including, [[myelopathy]], peripheral [[neuropathy]], and [[optic neuropathy]].<ref name="Jaiser, copper myelopathy" /><ref name="Kumar">{{cite journal | author = Kumar N | year = 2006 | title = Copper deficiency myelopathy (human swayback) | url = | journal = Mayo Clinic Proceedings | volume = 81 | issue = 10| pages = 1371–1384 | pmid = 17036563 | doi = 10.4065/81.10.1371 }}</ref>
=====Myelopathy===== Sufferers typically present difficulty walking ([[gait]] difficulty) caused by [[sensory ataxia]] (irregular muscle coordination) due to [[dorsal column]] dysfunction<ref name="Kumar" /> or degeneration of the spinal cord ([[myelopathy]]).<ref name="Jaiser, copper myelopathy" /><ref name="Jaiser, similar">Jaiser, S. R., & Winston, G. P. (2008). Copper deficiency myelopathy and subacute combined degeneration of the cord: why is the phenotype so similar?" ''Journal of Neurology'' 255, P569.</ref> Patients with ataxic gait have problems balancing and display an unstable wide walk. They often feel tremors in their torso, causing side way jerks and lunges.<ref name="Gait">Ataxic Gait Demonstration. Online Medical Video. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FpiEprzObIU&feature=related</ref>
In brain MRI, there is often an increased [[T2 (MRI)|T2]] signalling at the posterior columns of the spinal cord in patients with [[myelopathy]] caused by copper deficiency.<ref name="Jaiser, copper myelopathy" /><ref name="Kumar" /><ref name="MRI" /> T2 signalling is often an indicator of some kind of neurodegeneration. There are some changes in the spinal cord MRI involving the thoracic cord, the cervical cord or sometimes both.<ref name="Jaiser, copper myelopathy" /><ref name="Kumar" /> Copper deficiency myelopathy is often compared to [[subacute combined degeneration]] (SCD).<ref name="Jaiser, similar" /> [[Subacute combined degeneration]] is also a degeneration of the spinal cord, but instead [[vitamin B12]] deficiency is the cause of the spinal degeneration.<ref name="Jaiser, copper myelopathy" /> SCD also has the same high T2 signalling intensities in the posterior column as copper deficient patient in MRI imaging.<ref name="MRI">{{cite journal |author1=Bolamperti L. |author2=Leone M. A. |author3=Stecco A. |author4=Reggiani M. |author5=Pirisi M. |author6=Carriero A. | year = 2009 | title = Myeloneuropathy due to copper deficiency: clinical and MRI findings after copper supplementation. [Article] | url = | journal = Neurological Sciences | volume = 30 | issue = 6| pages = 521–524 | doi=10.1007/s10072-009-0126-7|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
=====Peripheral neuropathy===== Another common symptom of copper deficiency is [[peripheral neuropathy]], which is numbness or tingling that can start in the extremities and can sometimes progress radially inward towards the torso.<ref name="Kumar" /><ref name="Pineles">{{cite journal |author1=Pineles S. L. |author2=Wilson C. A. |author3=Balcer L. J. |author4=Slater R. |author5=Galetta S. L. | year = 2010 | title = Combined Optic Neuropathy and Myelopathy Secondary to Copper Deficiency. [Review] | url = | journal = Survey of Ophthalmology | volume = 55 | issue = 4| pages = 386–392 | doi=10.1016/j.survophthal.2010.02.002}}</ref> In an Advances in Clinical Neuroscience & Rehabilitation (ACNR) published case report, a 69-year-old patient had progressively worsened neurological symptoms.<ref name="Jaiser, masquerade">Jaiser, Stephan R. and Duddy, R. Copper Deficiency Masquerading as Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord and Myelodysplastic Syndrome. Advances in clinical neuroscience and rehabilitation, http://www.acnr.co.uk/JA07/ACNR_JA07_abnwinner.pdf</ref> These symptoms included diminished upper limb reflexes with abnormal lower limb reflexes, sensation to light touch and pin prick was diminished above the waist, vibration sensation was lost in the sternum, and markedly reduced [[proprioception]] or sensation about the self's orientation.<ref name="Jaiser, masquerade" /> Many people suffering from the neurological effects of copper deficiency complain about very similar or identical symptoms as the patient.<ref name="Jaiser, copper myelopathy" /><ref name="Pineles" /> This numbness and tingling poses danger for the elderly because it increases their risk of falling and injuring themselves. Peripheral [[neuropathy]] can become very disabling leaving some patients dependent on wheel chairs or walking canes for mobility if there is lack of correct diagnosis. Rarely can copper deficiency cause major disabling symptoms. The deficiency will have to be present for an extensive amount of time until such disabling conditions manifest.
=====Optic neuropathy===== Some patients suffering from copper deficiency have shown signs of vision and color loss.<ref name="Pineles" /> The vision is usually lost in the peripheral views of the eye.<ref name="Pineles" /> The bilateral vision loss is usually very gradual.<ref name="Pineles" /><ref name="Spinazzi">{{cite journal |author1=Spinazzi M. |author2=De Lazzari F. |author3=Tavolato B. |author4=Angelini C. |author5=Manara R. |author6=Armani M. | year = 2007 | title = Myelo-optico-neuropathy in copper deficiency occurring after partial gastrectomy. Do small bowel bacterial overgrowth syndrome and occult zinc ingestion tip the balance? | url = | journal = Journal of Neurology | volume = 254 | issue = 8| pages = 1012–1017 | doi=10.1007/s00415-006-0479-2 | pmid=17415508}}</ref> An [[optical coherence tomography]] (OCT) shows some nerve fiber layer loss in most patients, suggesting the vision loss and color vision loss was secondary to [[optic neuropathy]] or neurodegeneration.<ref name="Pineles" />
====Toxicity==== Copper toxicity can occur from excessive supplement use, eating acid foods cooked in uncoated copper cookware, exposure to excess copper in drinking water, or as the result of an inherited metabolic disorder in the case of [[Wilson's disease]]. A significant portion of the toxicity of copper comes from its ability to accept and donate single electrons as it changes oxidation state. This catalyzes the production of very reactive radical ions, such as [[hydroxyl radical]] in a manner similar to [[Fenton's reagent|Fenton chemistry]].<ref name=PubMed>{{cite journal | journal = Radiat Res. | author = Held KD | date = May 1996 | volume = 145 | issue = 5 |pages = 542–53 | title = Role of Fenton chemistry in thiol-induced toxicity and apoptosis | doi = 10.2307/3579272 | pmid = 8619019 | publisher = Radiation Research Society | jstor = 3579272| last2 = Sylvester | first2 = F. Craig | last3 = Hopcia | first3 = Karen L. | last4 = Biaglow | first4 = John E. | displayauthors = 1 }}</ref> This catalytic activity of copper is used by the enzymes with which it is associated, thus is only toxic when unsequestered and unmediated. This increase in unmediated reactive radicals is generally termed [[oxidative stress]], and is an active area of research in a variety of diseases where copper may play an important but more subtle role than in acute toxicity.
Some of the effects of aging may be associated with excess copper.<ref name="pmid17259340">{{cite journal |author=Brewer GJ |title=Iron and copper toxicity in diseases of aging, particularly atherosclerosis and Alzheimer's disease |journal=Exp. Biol. Med. (Maywood) |volume=232 |issue=2 |pages=323–35 |date=February 2007 |pmid=17259340 |doi= |url=http://www.ebmonline.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17259340}}</ref> In addition, studies have found that people with mental illnesses, such as [[schizophrenia]], had heightened levels of copper in their systems. However, it is unknown at this stage whether the copper contributes to the mental illness, whether the body attempts to store more copper in response to the illness, or whether the high levels of copper are the result of the mental illness.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Wolf T. L. |author2=Kotun J. |author3=Meador-Woodruff J. H. | year = 2006 | title = Plasma copper, iron, ceruloplasmin and ferroxidase activity in schizophrenia | url = | journal = Schizophrenia Research | volume = 86 | issue = 1| pages = 167–171 | doi=10.1016/j.schres.2006.05.027 | pmid=16842975}}</ref>
=====Alzheimer's disease===== Elevated free copper levels exist in [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref name="Brewer">{{cite journal | author = Brewer GJ |date=Apr 2010 | title = Copper toxicity in the general population | url = | journal = Clin Neurophysiol | volume = 121 | issue = 4| pages = 459–60 | doi = 10.1016/j.clinph.2009.12.015 | pmid = 20071223 }}</ref> Copper and zinc are known to bind to [[amyloid beta protein]]s in Alzheimer's disease.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=[[Chembiochem]] |date=2009-12-14 |volume=10 |issue=18 |pages=2837–45 |title=Copper and zinc binding to amyloid-beta: coordination, dynamics, aggregation, reactivity and metal-ion transfer |author=Faller P |pmid=19877000 |doi= 10.1002/cbic.200900321 }}</ref> This bound form is thought to mediate the production of [[reactive oxygen species]] in the brain.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=[[Biochimie]] |date=October 2009 |volume=91 |issue=10 |pages=1212–7 |title=Abeta-mediated ROS production by Cu ions: structural insights, mechanisms and relevance to Alzheimer's disease |author=Hureau C, Faller P |pmid=19332103 |doi=10.1016/j.biochi.2009.03.013 |last2=Faller }}</ref> A preliminary clinical trial suggests that zinc supplementation may be able to decrease copper levels and slow degeneration in Alzheimer's disease.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Brewer G. J. | year = 2012 | title = Copper excess, zinc deficiency, and cognition loss in Alzheimer's disease | url = | journal = BioFactors | volume = 38 | issue = 2| pages = 107–113 | doi=10.1002/biof.1005 | pmid=22438177}}</ref>
===Manganese=== Manganese is a component of some [[enzymes]] and stimulates the development and activity of other enzymes. Manganese superoxide dismutase (MnSOD) is the principal [[antioxidant]] in [[mitochondria]]. Several enzymes activated by manganese contribute to the [[metabolism]] of [[carbohydrates]], [[amino acids]], and [[cholesterol]].<ref>Food and Nutrition Board, Institute of Medicine. Manganese. Dietary reference intakes for vitamin A, vitamin K, boron, chromium, copper, iodine, iron, manganese, molybdenum, nickel, silicon, vanadium, and zinc. Washington, D.C.: National Academy Press; 2001:394-419. (National Academy Press)</ref>
Deficiency of manganese causes skeletal deformation in animals and inhibits the production of [[collagen]] in wound healing.<ref>Keen CL, Zidenberg-Cherr S. Manganese. In: Ziegler EE, Filer LJ, eds. Present Knowledge in Nutrition. 7th ed. Washington D.C.: ILSI Press; 1996:334-343.</ref> On the other hand, manganese toxicity is associated with neurological complications.<ref name="pmid16629164">{{cite journal |author=Roth JA |title=Homeostatic and toxic mechanisms regulating manganese uptake, retention, and elimination |journal=Biol. Res. |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=45–57 |year=2006 |pmid=16629164 |doi=10.4067/S0716-97602006000100006}}</ref>
====Toxicity==== Manganese poisoning is a [[toxic]] condition resulting from chronic exposure to [[manganese]] and first identified in 1837 by [[James Couper (academic)|James Couper]].<ref name="Couper1837">{{cite journal | last = Couper | first = J. | title = Sur les effets du peroxide de manganèse | journal = Journal de chimie médicale, de pharmacie et de toxicologie | year= 1837 | volume = 3 | pages= 223–225 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=WpQ3AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA233}}</ref>
=====Presentation===== Chronic exposure to excessive Mn levels can lead to a variety of psychiatric and motor disturbances, termed [[manganism]]. Generally, exposure to ambient Mn air concentrations in excess of 5 mg Mn/m3 can lead to Mn-induced symptoms.<ref name="libres.uncg.edu">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1471-4159.2009.06534.x | url = http://libres.uncg.edu/ir/uncg/f/K_Erickson_Ferroportin_2009.pdf | title = Ferroportin is a manganese-responsive protein that decreases manganese cytotoxicity and accumulation | year = 2010 | last1 = Yin | first1 = Zhaobao | last2 = Jiang | first2 = Haiyan | last3 = Lee | first3 = Eun-Sook Y. | last4 = Ni | first4 = Mingwei | last5 = Erikson | first5 = Keith M. | last6 = Milatovic | first6 = Dejan | last7 = Bowman | first7 = Aaron B. | last8 = Aschner | first8 = Michael | journal = Journal of Neurochemistry | volume = 112 | issue = 5 | pages = 1190–8 | pmid = 20002294 | pmc = 2819584}}</ref>
In initial stages of manganism, neurological symptoms consist of reduced response speed, irritability, mood changes, and compulsive behaviors.<ref name="pmid16629164"/> Upon protracted exposure symptoms are more prominent and resemble those of [[idiopathic]] [[Parkinson's disease]], as which it is often misdiagnosed, although there are particular differences in both the symptoms (nature of tremors, for example), response to drugs such as [[L-DOPA|levodopa]], and affected portion of the [[basal ganglia]]. Symptoms are also similar to [[Motor neurone disease|Lou Gehrig's disease]] and [[multiple sclerosis]].
=====Causes===== Manganism has become an active issue in [[occupational safety and health|workplace safety]] as it has been the subject of numerous [[product liability]] lawsuits against manufacturers of [[arc welding]] supplies. In these lawsuits, welders have accused the manufacturers of failing to provide adequate warning that their products could cause welding fumes to contain dangerously high manganese concentrations that could lead welders to develop manganism. Companies employing welders are also being sued, for what colloquially is known as "welders' disease". However, studies fail to show any link between employment as a welder and manganism (or other neurological problems).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fryzek JP, Hansen J, Cohen S, Bonde JP, Llambias MT, Kolstad HA, Skytthe A, Lipworth L, Blot WJ, Olsen JH | date = May 2005 | title = A cohort study of Parkinson's disease and other neurodegenerative disorders in Danish welders | url = http://www.weldinginfonetwork.com/studies/05_05_Danish_JOEM.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine | volume = 47 | issue = 5| pages = 466–72 | doi=10.1097/01.jom.0000161730.25913.bf| pmid = 15891525 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1136/oem.2005.022921| pages = 135–40 | title = Parkinson's disease and other basal ganglia or movement disorders in a large nationwide cohort of Swedish welders | year = 2006 | last1 = Fored | first1 = C M | journal = Occupational and Environmental Medicine | volume = 63 | issue = 2 | pmid = 16421393 | last2 = Fryzek | first2 = JP | last3 = Brandt | first3 = L | last4 = Nise | first4 = G | last5 = Sjögren | first5 = B | last6 = McLaughlin | first6 = JK | last7 = Blot | first7 = WJ | last8 = Ekbom | first8 = A | pmc = 2078076}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Marsh GM, Gula MJ |date=Oct 2006 | title = Employment as a welder and Parkinson disease among heavy equipment manufacturing workers | url = http://journals.lww.com/joem/Abstract/2006/10000/Employment_as_a_Welder_and_Parkinson_Disease_Among.12.aspx | journal = Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine | volume = 48 | issue = 10| pages = 1031–46 | doi=10.1097/01.jom.0000232547.74802.d8|pmid=17033503 |last2=Gula }}</ref>
Manganism is also documented in reports of illicit [[methcathinone]] manufacturing.<ref name="pmid17562938">{{cite journal |author=de Bie RM, Gladstone RM, Strafella AP, Ko JH, Lang AE |title=Manganese-induced Parkinsonism associated with methcathinone (Ephedrone) abuse |journal=[[Arch. Neurol.]] |volume=64 |issue=6 |pages=886–9 |date=June 2007 |pmid=17562938 |doi=10.1001/archneur.64.6.886 |url=http://archneur.ama-assn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17562938 |last2=Gladstone |last3=Strafella |last4=Ko |last5=Lang }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> This is due to manganese being a byproduct of methcathinone synthesis if [[potassium permanganate]] is used as an oxidiser.<ref name="pmid17566121">{{cite journal |author= Sanotsky, Y., Lesyk, R., Fedoryshyn, L., Komnatska, I., Matviyenko, Y. and Fahn, S.|title=Manganic encephalopathy due to "ephedrone" abuse |journal=[[Movement Disorders (journal)|Movement Disorders]] |volume=22 |issue= 9|pages=1337–1343 |date=June 2007 |pmid=17566121 |doi=10.1002/mds.21378}}</ref> Symptoms include apathy, bradykinesia, gait disorder with postural instability, and spastic-hypokinetic dysarthria. Another street drug sometimes contaminated with manganese is the so-called "Bazooka", prepared by [[Freebase (chemistry)|free-base]] methods from [[cocaine]] using manganese [[carbonate]].<ref name="bazooka">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1093/jat/9.1.45 | pmid = 3981975| pages = 45–46| title = Bazooka: Cocaine-Base and Manganese Carbonate| journal = Journal of Analytical Toxicology| volume = 9| issue = 1| year = 1985| last1 = Ensing| first1 = J. G.}}</ref>
Reports also mention such sources as contaminated drinking water,<ref name="water">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/00039896.1989.9935883| pages = 175–178 | title = Possible Health Effects of High Manganese Concentration in Drinking Water | year = 1989 | last1 = Kondakis | first1 = Xenophon G. | last2 = Makris | first2 = Nicolas | last3 = Leotsinidis | first3 = Michael | last4 = Prinou | first4 = Mary | last5 = Papapetropoulos | first5 = Theodore | journal = Archives of Environmental Health | volume = 44 | issue = 3}}</ref> and fuel additive [[methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl]] (MMT),<ref name="MMT">{{cite journal | pmid= 10385898| pages = 379–397 | year= 1999 | last1= Hudnell | first1= HK | title= Effects from environmental Mn exposures: A review of the evidence from non-occupational exposure studies | volume= 20 | issue= 2–3 | journal= Neurotoxicology}}</ref> which on [[combustion]] becomes partially converted into manganese [[phosphate]]s and [[sulfate]] that go airborne with the exhaust,<ref name="MMT2">{{cite journal | pmid = 10385878| pages= 145–150 | year = 1999 | last1 = Lynam | first1 = DR | last2 = Roos | first2 = JW | last3 = Pfeifer | first3 = GD | last4 = Fort | first4 = BF | last5 = Pullin | first5 = TG | title = Environmental effects and exposures to manganese from use of methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl (MMT) in gasoline | volume = 20 | issue = 2–3 | journal = Neurotoxicology}}</ref><ref name="MMT3">Reynolds JG, Roos JW, Wong J, Deutsch SE. Manganese particulates from vehicles using MMT fuel. In 15th International Neurotoxicology Conference, Little Rock, AK, 1997.</ref><ref name="MMT4">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0048-9697(90)90098-F | pages = 107–114 | title = Environmental assessment of MMT™ fuel additive | year = 1990 | last1 = Lynam | first1 = D.R. | last2 = Pfeifer | first2 = G.D. | last3 = Fort | first3 = B.F. | last4 = Gelbcke | first4 = A.A. | journal = Science of the Total Environment | volume = 93 | pmid = 2113712| bibcode = 1990ScTEn..93..107L }}</ref> and [[manganese ethylene-bis-dithiocarbamate]] ([[Maneb]]), a pesticide.<ref name="maneb">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1212/WNL.38.4.550 | pages = 550–553 | title = Chronic exposure to the fungicide maneb may produce symptoms and signs of CNS manganese intoxication | year = 1988 | last1 = Ferraz | first1 = H. B. | last2 = f. Bertolucci | first2 = P. H. | last3 = Pereira | first3 = J. S. | last4 = Lima | first4 = J.G.C. | last5 = f. Andrade | first5 = L. A. | journal = Neurology | volume = 38 | issue = 4 | pmid = 3352909}}</ref>
=====Pathological mechanisms===== Manganese may affect [[liver]] function, but the threshold of acute toxicity is very high. On the other hand, more than 95% of manganese is eliminated by biliary excretion. Any existing liver damage may slow this process, increasing its concentration in blood plasma.<ref name="Ballatori2000">Ballatori N. Molecular mechanisms of hepatic metal transport. In Molecular Biology and Toxicology of Metals, Zalups RK, Koropatnick J (eds). Taylor & Francis: New York, 2000; 346-381.</ref> The exact [[neurotoxic]] mechanism of manganese is uncertain but there are clues pointing at the interaction of manganese with [[iron]],<ref name="Verity1999">{{cite journal | pmid= 10385907 | pages = 489–497 | year= 1999 | last1= Verity | first1= MA | title= Manganese neurotoxicity: A mechanistic hypothesis | volume= 20 | issue= 2–3 | journal= Neurotoxicology}} </ref><ref name="Zheng2001">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0006-8993(01)02049-2 | pages = 175–179 | title = Iron overload following manganese exposure in cultured neuronal, but not neuroglial cells | year = 2001 | last1 = Zheng | first1 = Wei | last2 = Zhao | first2 = Qiuqu | journal = Brain Research | volume = 897 | pmid = 11282372 | issue = 1–2}}</ref><ref name="Zheng1999">{{cite journal | doi =10.1016/S0006-8993(99)01558-9 | pages = 125–132 | title =Alteration of iron homeostasis following chronic exposure to manganese in rats | year =1999 | last1 =Zheng | first1 =Wei | last2 =Zhao | first2 =Qiuqu | last3 =Slavkovich | first3 =Vesna | last4 =Aschner | first4 =Michael | last5 =Graziano | first5 =Joseph H | journal =Brain Research | volume =833 | pmid =10375687 | issue =1}}</ref><ref name="Zheng2001_2">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1081/CLT-100108512| url = http://web.ics.purdue.edu/~wzheng/Publications/Epapers/2001_Zheng%20JToxClinTox_BBB%20Review.pdf | pages = 711–719 | title = Neurotoxicology of the Brain Barrier System: New Implications | year = 2001 | last1 = Zheng | first1 = Wei | journal = Clinical Toxicology | volume = 39 | issue = 7 | pmid = 11778669| pmc = 4111935 }}</ref> [[zinc]],<ref name="Lai1999">{{cite journal | pmid =10385902 | pages =433–444 | year =1999 | last1 =Lai | first1 =JC | last2 =Minski | first2 =MJ | last3 =Chan | first3 =AW | last4 =Leung | first4 =TK | last5 =Lim | first5 =L | title =Manganese mineral interactions in brain | volume =20 | issue =2–3 | journal =Neurotoxicology}}</ref> [[aluminum]],<ref name="Verity1999" /><ref name="Lai1999"/> and [[copper]].<ref name="Lai1999" /> Based on a number of studies, disturbed iron [[metabolism]] could underlie the neurotoxic action of manganese.<ref>{{cite journal | doi =10.1016/S0006-8993(98)00481-8 | pages =334–342 | title =Manganese inhibits mitochondrial aconitase: A mechanism of manganese neurotoxicity | year =1998 | last1 =Zheng | first1 =Wei | last2 =Ren | first2 =Sean | last3 =Graziano | first3 =Joseph H. | journal =Brain Research | volume =799 | issue =2 | pmid =9675333}}</ref>
It participates in [[Fenton reaction]]s and could thus induce [[oxidative damage]], a hypothesis corroborated by the evidence from studies of affected welders.<ref name="Li2004">{{cite journal | author = Li G, Zhang L, Lu L, Wu P, Zheng W | year = 2004 | title = Occupational exposure to welding fume among welders: alterations of manganese, iron, zinc, copper, and lead in body fluids and the oxidative stress status | url = | journal = J. Occup. Environ. Med. | volume = 46 | issue = 3| pages = 241–248 | doi=10.1097/01.jom.0000116900.49159.03}}</ref> A study of the exposed workers showed that they have significantly fewer children.<ref name="Lauwerys1985">{{cite journal |author=Lauwerys, Robert;|title=Fertility of male workers exposed to mercury vapor or to manganese dust: A questionnaire study |journal=American Journal of Industrial Medicine |volume=7 |issue=2 | doi =10.1002/ajim.4700070208 |pmid=3976664 | pages= 171–176.|year=1985 |displayauthors=etal }}</ref> This may indicate that long-term [[wikt:accumulation|accumulation]] of manganese affects [[fertility]]. Pregnant animals repeatedly receiving high doses of manganese bore malformed offspring significantly more often compared to controls.<ref name="Treinen1995">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1002/tera.1420520207 | pages= 109–115 | title = Developmental toxicity of mangafodipir trisodium and manganese chloride in Sprague-Dawley rats | year = 1995 | last1 = Treinen | first1 = Kimberley A. | last2 = Gray | first2 = Tim J. B. | last3 = Blazak | first3 = William F. | journal = Teratology | volume = 52 | issue = 2 | pmid = 8588182}}</ref> Manganism mimics Schizophrenia.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=6129921 | volume=60 | issue=11 | title=Manganese neurotoxicity: a model for free radical mediated neurodegeneration? | year=1982 | journal=Can. J. Physiol. Pharmacol. | pages=1398–405 | doi=10.1139/y82-208 |vauthors=Donaldson J, McGregor D, LaBella F }}</ref> It is found in large quantities in paint and steelmaking.
=====Treatment===== The current mainstay of manganism treatment is [[levodopa]] and [[chelation]] with [[EDTA]]. Both have limited and at best transient efficacy. Replenishing the deficit of [[dopamine]] with levodopa has been shown to initially improve [[extrapyramidal symptom]]s,<ref name="Lee2000">{{cite journal | doi =10.1001/archneur.57.4.597 | pages= 597–599 | title =Manganese Intoxication | year =2000 | last1 =Lee | first1 =J.-W. | journal =Archives of Neurology | volume =57 | issue =4 | pmid =10768639}}</ref><ref name="Mena1970">Mena I, Court J, Fuenzalida S, Papavasiliou PS, Cotzias GC. [http://journals.lww.com/joem/Citation/1970/05000/Modification_of_Chronic_Manganese_Poisoning_.25.aspx Modification of chronic manganese poisoning. Treatment with Ldopa or 5-OH tryptophane]. New Engl. J. Med. 1970; 282(1) 5-10.</ref><ref name="Rosenstock1971">{{cite journal | doi =10.1001/jama.1971.03190100038007 | pages= 1354–1358 | title =Chronic Manganism: Neurologic and Laboratory Studies During Treatment with Levodopa | year =1971 | last1 =Rosenstock | first1 =Harvey A. | journal =JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association | volume =217 | issue =10}}</ref> but the response to treatment goes down after 2 or 3 years,<ref name="Huang1993">{{cite journal | doi =10.1212/WNL.43.8.1479 | pages= 1479–1483 | title =Progression after chronic manganese exposure | year =1993 | last1 =Huang | first1 =C.-C. | last2 =Lu | first2 =C.-S. | last3 =Chu | first3 =N.-S. | last4 =Hochberg | first4 =F. | last5 =Lilienfeld | first5 =D. | last6 =Olanow | first6 =W. | last7 =Calne | first7 =D. B. | journal =Neurology | volume =43 | issue =8 | pmid =8351000}}</ref> with worsening condition of the same patients noted even after 10 years since last exposure to manganese.<ref name="Huang1998">{{cite journal | doi =10.1212/WNL.50.3.698 |pages = 698–700 | title =Long-term progression in chronic manganism: Ten years of follow-up | year =1998 | last1 =Huang | first1 =C.-C. | last2 =Chu | first2 =N.-S. | last3 =Lu | first3 =C.-S. | last4 =Chen | first4 =R.-S. | last5 =Calne | first5 =D. B. | journal =Neurology | volume =50 | issue =3 | pmid =9521259}}</ref> Enhanced excretion of manganese prompted by chelation therapy brings its blood levels down but the symptoms remain largely unchanged, raising questions about efficacy of this form of treatment.<ref name="Ono2002">{{cite journal | doi =10.1016/S0022-510X(02)00111-9 | pages= 93–96 | title =Myoclonic involuntary movement associated with chronic manganese poisoning | year =2002 | last1 =Ono | first1 =Kenjiro | last2 =Komai | first2 =Kiyonobu | last3 =Yamada | first3 =Masahito | journal =Journal of the Neurological Sciences | volume =199 | pmid =12084450 | issue =1–2}}</ref><ref name="Calne_etal">{{cite journal |pmid = 7936278 | pages = 1583–1586 |year = 1994 |last1 = Calne |first1 = DB |last2 = Chu |first2 = NS |last3 = Huang |first3 = CC |last4 = Lu |first4 = CS |last5 = Olanow |first5 = W |title = Manganism and idiopathic parkinsonism: Similarities and differences |volume = 44 |issue = 9 |journal = Neurology |doi = 10.1212/WNL.44.9.1583}}</ref>
Increased [[ferroportin]] protein expression in human embryonic kidney (HEK293) cells is associated with decreased intracellular Mn concentration and attenuated cytotoxicity, characterized by the reversal of Mn-reduced [[glutamate]] uptake and diminished [[lactate dehydrogenase]] (LDH) leakage.<ref name="libres.uncg.edu"/>
=====Locations===== The [[Red River Delta]] near [[Hanoi]] has high levels of manganese or [[arsenic]] in the water. Approximately 65 percent of the region’s wells contain high levels of arsenic, manganese, selenium and barium.<ref>http://www.watertechonline.com/news.asp?N_ID=75635{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> This was also published in the [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]].
===Magnesium=== Magnesium is necessary for the function of many metabolic enzymes and also serves as a key regulator of calcium channels involved in neurotransmission (e.g. NMDA receptor).<ref>Nowak, L., Bregestovski, P., Ascher, P., Herbet, A., & Prochiantz, A. (1984). Magnesium gates glutamate-activated channels in mouse central neurones.</ref> Magnesium supplementation facilitates nerve regeneration after injury.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Pan H. C. |author2=Sheu M. L. |author3=Su H. L. |author4=Chen Y. J. |author5=Chen C. J. |author6=Yang D. Y. |author7=Cheng F. C. | year = 2011 | title = Magnesium supplement promotes sciatic nerve regeneration and down-regulates inflammatory response | url = | journal = Magnesium Research | volume = 24 | issue = | pages = 54–70 }}</ref> Although unpolished grains contain magnesium, phytic acid in grains can inhibit its absorption. Leafy greens are an excellent source of magnesium.<ref>FDA DRI Report on Magnesium http://www.nal.usda.gov/fnic/DRI//DRI_Calcium/190-249.pdf</ref>
==Vitamins== Deficiency or excess intake of many vitamins can affect the brain contributing to developmental<ref>McCann, J. C., & Ames, B. N. (2010). 24 Evidence Required for Causal Inferences about Effects of Micronutrient Deficiencies during Development on Brain Health. Micronutrients and Brain Health, 355.</ref> and degenerative diseases.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Ames B. N. | year = 2006 | title = Low micronutrient intake may accelerate the degenerative diseases of aging through allocation of scarce micronutrients by triage | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 103 | issue = 47| pages = 17589–17594 | doi=10.1073/pnas.0608757103| bibcode = 2006PNAS..10317589A | pmid=17101959 | pmc=1693790}}</ref>
===Vitamin A=== [[Vitamin A]] is an essential [[nutrient]] for mammals which takes form in either [[retinol]] or the [[provitamin]] [[beta-Carotene]]. It helps regulation of cell division, cell function, genetic regulation, helps enhance the immune system, and is required for brain function, chemical balance, growth and development of the [[central nervous system]] and vision.<ref name="Edem D.O">{{cite journal |doi=10.3923/ajcn.2009.65.82 |title=Vitamin A: A Review |year=2009 |last1=Edem |first1=D.O. |journal=Asian Journal of Clinical Nutrition |volume=1 |pages=65–82}}</ref>
====Learning memory==== In an experiment by [[Chongqing Medical University]] pregnant rats were either plentiful in vitamin A or were of a [[vitamin A deficiency]] (VAD) due to their diet. The offspring of these rats were then tested in a water maze at 8 weeks old and it was found the VAD offspring had a harder time finishing the maze which helps show that these rats, even while having a deficiency from ''[[in utero]]'', have more problems with learning memory.<ref name="Ting-Yu L et.al. (Pregnancy)">{{cite journal |doi=10.1542/peds.2007-2022NNNNNN |title=Marginal Vitamin a Deficiency in Pregnancy Can Induce Memory Deficit in Adult Offspring |year=2008 |last1=Li |first1=T.-Y. |last2=Huang |first2=H.-M. |last3=Mao |first3=C.-T. |last4=Liu |first4=Y. |last5=Qu |first5=P. |last6=Yang |first6=L. |journal=Pediatrics |volume=121 |pages=S152}}</ref> Young rats in a separate study by the same university also showed impaired [[long-term potentiation]] in the [[hippocampus]] when they were VAD which shows neuronal impairment.<ref name="Ting-Yu L et.al. (LTP)">{{cite journal |doi=10.1542/peds.2007-2022OOOOOO |title=Effects of Marginal Vitamin a Deficiency on Long-Term Potentiation in Young Rats |year=2008 |last1=Li |first1=T.-Y. |last2=Mao |first2=C.-T. |last3=Huang |first3=H.-M. |last4=Liu |first4=Y.-X. |last5=Qu |first5=P. |last6=Yang |first6=L. |journal=Pediatrics |volume=121 |pages=S153}}</ref> When the patient is VAD for too long, the effects of the damage to the [[hippocampus]] can be irreversible.<ref name="Etchamendy et.al.">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0166-4328(03)00099-8 |title=Vitamin a deficiency and relational memory deficit in adult mice: Relationships with changes in brain retinoid signalling |year=2003 |last1=Etchamendy |first1=Nicole |last2=Enderlin |first2=Valérie |last3=Marighetto |first3=Aline |last4=Pallet |first4=Véronique |last5=Higueret |first5=Paul |last6=Jaffard |first6=Robert |journal=Behavioural Brain Research |volume=145 |pages=37–49 |pmid=14529804 |issue=1–2}}</ref>
====Spatial memory==== Vitamin A affects spatial memory most of the time because the size of the [[Cell nucleus|nuclei]] in hippocampal neurons are reduced by approximately 70% when there is a deficiency which affects a person's abilities for higher cognitive function. In a study by the University of Cagliari, Italy, VAD rats had more trouble learning a [[Radial arm maze]] than rats who had normal levels of the [[vitamin]]. The healthy rats were able to correctly solve the maze within the 15-day training period and other rats that were once deficient but had vitamin A restored to normal levels were also able to solve it. Here it was found that the [[retinoid receptors]] which help transport vitamin A were of normal function.<ref name="Cocco S et.al.">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0306-4522(02)00423-2 |title=Vitamin a deficiency produces spatial learning and memory impairment in rats |year=2002 |last1=Cocco |first1=S |last2=Diaz |first2=G |last3=Stancampiano |first3=R |last4=Diana |first4=A |last5=Carta |first5=M |last6=Curreli |first6=R |last7=Sarais |first7=L |last8=Fadda |first8=F |journal=Neuroscience |volume=115 |issue=2 |pages=475–82 |pmid=12421614}}</ref>
====Prevention, treatment and symptoms==== Eating foods high in vitamin A or taking [[dietary supplements]], retinol or [[retinal]] will prevent a deficiency. The foods highest in vitamin A are any pigmented fruits and vegetables and leafy green vegetables also provide [[beta-Carotene]].<ref name="Edem D.O"/> There can be symptoms of fat loss and a reduction of any weight gain that would be considered normal for an individual,<ref name="Cocco S et.al."/> especially developmental weight gains such as in infants which would occur if the infant was deprived of vitamin A [[in utero]] and/or if it was deprived [[postnatal]] for an extensive period of time.<ref name="Ting-Yu L et.al. (Pregnancy)"/> The deficiency can also cause conditions such as [[blindness]] or night blindness, also known as [[nyctalopia]]. Night blindness is due to the inability to regenerate [[rhodopsin]] in the [[Rod cell|rods]] which is needed in dim light in order to see properly.<ref name="Edem D.O"/> A treatment of supplements of [[retinoic acid]] which is a part of vitamin A can help replenish levels and help bring learning to normal,<ref name="Hermandez-Pinto Puelble-Jimenez and Arilla-Ferreiro">{{cite journal |doi= 10.1016/j.neuroscience.2006.04.034 |title= A vitamin A-free diet results in impairment of the rat hippocampal somatostatinergic system |year= 2006 |last1= Hernández-Pinto |first1= A.M. |last2= Puebla-Jiménez |first2= L. |last3= Arilla-Ferreiro |first3= E. |journal= Neuroscience |volume= 141 |issue= 2 |pages= 851–61 |pmid= 16757122}}</ref> but after 39 weeks this is ineffective even if the treatment is daily because it will not bring the [[retinoid]] hypo-signalling back to normal.<ref name="Etchamendy et.al."/>
====Relationship with zinc==== Zinc is needed to maintain normal vitamin A levels in [[blood plasma]].<ref name="Edem D.O"/> It also helps vitamin A become [[Metabolism|metabolized]] by the [[liver]]. However evidence suggests that when someone is deficient in both vitamin A and zinc, memory is more improved when just vitamin A is increased than when just zinc is increased. Of course [[memory]] has the largest improvement when both are increased. When one of these nutrients is not balanced, the other is most likely to be affected because they rely on each other for proper functioning in learning.<ref name="Kheirvari et al.">{{cite journal |doi=10.3177/jnsv.52.421 |title=Increased Nerve Growth Factor by Zinc Supplementation with Concurrent Vitamin a Deficiency Does Not Improve Memory Performance in Mice |year=2006 |last1=Kheirvari |first1=Sorayya |last2=Uezu |first2=Kayoko |last3=Sakai |first3=Tohru |last4=Nakamori |first4=Masayo |last5=Alizadeh |first5=Mohammad |last6=Sarukura |first6=Nobuko |last7=Yamamoto |first7=Shigeru |journal=Journal of Nutritional Science and Vitaminology |volume=52 |issue=6 |pages=421–7 |pmid=17330505}}</ref>
===Thiamin (vitamin B1)=== Vitamin B<sub>1</sub>, also known as thiamine, is a [[Cofactor (biochemistry)|coenzyme]] essential for the metabolism of [[carbohydrates]].<ref name= delta>{{Cite journal |last1=Ogershok |first1=Paul R. |last2=Rahman |first2=Aamer |last3=Nestor |first3=Scott |last4=Brick |first4=James |title=Wernicke Encephalopathy in Nonalcoholic Patients |journal=American Journal of the Medical Sciences |pmid=11863078 |url=http://meta.wkhealth.com/pt/pt-core/template-journal/lwwgateway/media/landingpage.htm?issn=0002-9629&volume=323&issue=2&spage=107 |year=2002 |volume=323 |issue=2 |pages=107–11 |doi=10.1097/00000441-200202000-00010}}</ref> This vitamin is important for the facilitation of glucose use, thus ensuring the production of energy for the brain,<ref name="bravo">{{Cite journal |pmid=17066209 |year=2006 |last1=Bourre |first1=JM |title=Effects of nutrients (in food) on the structure and function of the nervous system: Update on dietary requirements for brain. Part 1: Micronutrients |volume=10 |issue=5 |pages=377–85 |journal=The Journal of Nutrition, Health & Aging}}</ref> and normal functioning of the nervous system, muscles, and heart.<ref name="charlie">{{Cite journal |pmid=16245676 |year=2005 |last1=Thompson |first1=J |title=Vitamins, minerals and supplements: Part two |volume=78 |issue=10 |pages=366–8 |journal=Community Practitioner}}</ref>
Thiamine is found in all living [[Tissue (biology)|tissues]],<ref name= echo>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1016/0892-0362(91)90083-9 |title=Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff's psychosis: To fortify or not to fortify? |year=1991 |last1=Bond |first1=Nigel W. |last2=Homewood |first2=Judi |journal=Neurotoxicology and Teratology |volume=13 |issue=4 |pages=353–5 |pmid=1921914}}</ref> and is uniformly distributed throughout mammalian nervous tissue, including the brain and [[spinal cord]]. Metabolism and coenzyme function of the vitamin suggest a distinctive function for thiamin within the [[nervous system]].<ref name= foxtrot>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1007/BF00964146 |title=The role of thiamine in nervous tissue |year=1979 |last1=Cooper |first1=Jack R. |last2=Pincus |first2=Jonathan H. |journal=Neurochemical Research |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=223–39 |pmid=37452}}</ref>
The brain retains its thiamine content in the face of a vitamin-deficient diet with great tenacity, as it is the last of all nervous tissues studied to become depleted. A 50% reduction of thiamine stores in [[rat]]s becomes apparent after only 4 days of being put on a thiamine-deficient diet. However, polyneuritic signs do not begin to appear until about 4 or 5 weeks have passed.<ref name="foxtrot"/> Similar results have been found in human subjects.<ref name="echo" />
====Deficiencies==== The body has only small stores of B<sub>1</sub>; accordingly, there is risk of deficiency if the level of intake is reduced only for a few weeks.<ref name="echo"/> Thiamin deficiency during critical periods of early development can disrupts neurogenesis in animal models.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Bâ A | year = 2011 | title = Comparative effects of alcohol and thiamine deficiency on the developing central nervous system | url = | journal = Behavioural Brain Research | volume = 225 | issue = 1| pages = 235–242 | doi=10.1016/j.bbr.2011.07.015 | pmid=21784107}}</ref> Lack of thiamin later in life causes the disease known as beriberi.<ref name= golf>{{cite book |title=Dietary Reference Intakes for Thiamin, Riboflavin, Niacin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Vitamin B12, Pantothenic Acid, Biotin, and Choline |year=1998 |publisher=National Academy Press |location=Washington, DC |isbn=0-309-06554-2 |url=http://www.nal.usda.gov/fnic/DRI/DRI_Thiamin/58-86_150.pdf |accessdate=2012}}{{page needed|was " |page=58 |pages=1–541". which is it?|date=July 2012}}</ref> There are two forms of [[beriberi]]: "wet", and "dry". Dry beriberi is also known as cerebral beriberi. Characteristics of wet beriberi include prominent [[edema]] and [[Heart|cardiac involvement]], whereas dry beriberi is mainly characterized by a [[Peripheral neuropathy|polyneuritis]].<ref name="foxtrot"/> Severe thiamin deficiency can also result in acute neurodegeneration leading to peripheral neuropathy and memory loss.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Richardson S. |author2=Malhotra A. |author3=Cwynarski K. |author4=Hughes D. |author5=Prentice A. |author6=McNamara C. | year = 2010 | title = Patients undergoing high dose chemotherapy for primary CNS lymphoma should receive prophylactic thiamine to prevent Wernike's encephalopathy | url = | journal = British Journal of Haematology | volume = 149 | issue = 6| pages = 899–901 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2141.2010.08112.x|pmid=20151977 }}</ref>
In industrialized nations, thiamine deficiency is a clinically significant problem in individuals with chronic alcoholism or other disorders that interfere with normal ingestion of food.<ref name= hotel>{{cite journal |doi=10.2174/1566524013363870 |title=Molecular Mechanisms of Thiamine Utilization |year=2001 |last1=Singleton. |first1=C.K. |last2=Martin |first2=P.R. |journal=Current Molecular Medicine |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=197–207 |pmid=11899071}}</ref> Thiamine deficiency within developed nations tends to manifest as [[Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome]].<ref name="golf"/> Chronic alcoholism can disrupt thiamin absorption and thiamin deficiency contributes to neurodegeneration and memory loss in alcoholics known as Wernicke's encephalopathy.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Pitel A. L., Zahr N. M., Jackson K., Sassoon S. A., Rosenbloom M. J., Pfefferbaum A., Sullivan E. V. | year = 2010 | title = Signs of preclinical Wernicke's encephalopathy and thiamine levels as predictors of neuropsychological deficits in alcoholism without Korsakoff's syndrome | url = | journal = Neuropsychopharmacology | volume = 36 | issue = 3| pages = 580–588 | pmid = 20962766 | last2 = Zahr | last3 = Jackson | last4 = Sassoon | last5 = Rosenbloom | last6 = Pfefferbaum | last7 = Sullivan | doi = 10.1038/npp.2010.189 | pmc = 3055684 }}</ref> Individuals with chronic [[alcoholism]] may fall short on minimum [[Reference Daily Intake|daily requirements]] of thiamine in part due to [[Anorexia (symptom)|anorexia]], erratic eating habits, lack of available food, or a combination of any of these factors. Thiamine deficiency has been reported in up to 80% of alcoholic patients due to inadequate nutritional intake, reduced absorption, and impaired utilization of thiamine.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1530-0277.1983.tb05403.x |title=Alcohol and Thiamine Metabolism |year=1983 |last1=Hoyumpa |first1=Anastacio M. |journal=Alcoholism: Clinical and Experimental Research |volume=7 |pages=11–14}}</ref> Alcohol, in combination with its [[metabolite]] [[acetaldehyde]], interacts with thiamine utilization at the molecular level during transport, diphosphorylation, and modification processes. For this reason, chronic alcoholics may have insufficient thiamine for maintenance of normal brain function, even with seemingly adequate dietary intake.<ref name="hotel"/>
====Symptoms==== Clinical signs of B<sub>1</sub> deficiency include mental changes such as apathy, decrease in [[short-term memory]], confusion, and irritability.<ref name="golf"/> Moderate deficiency in thiamine may reduce growth in young populations, in increase chronic illness in both young and middle-aged adults. In addition, moderate deficiency of thiamine may increase rates of [[Depression (mood)|depression]], [[dementia]], falls, and [[fracture]]s in old age.<ref name="hotel"/>
The lingering symptoms of neuropathy associated with cerebral beriberi are known as [[Korsakoff's syndrome]], or the chronic phase of Wernicke-Korsakoff's.<ref name= india>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/jnnp.42.3.226 |title=Wernicke's encephalopathy: A more common disease than realised. A neuropathological study of 51 cases |year=1979 |last1=Harper |first1=C |journal=Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry |volume=42 |issue=3 |pages=226–31 |pmid=438830 |pmc=490724}}</ref> Wernicke encephalopathy is a neurological disorder resulting from a deficiency in thiamine, sharing the same predominant features of cerebral beriberi, as characterized by ocular abnormalities, [[Gait abnormality|ataxia of gait]], a global state of confusion, and neuropathy.<ref name="hotel"/> The state of confusion associated with Wernicke's may consist of apathy, inattention, spatial disorientation, inability to concentrate, and mental sluggishness or restlessness.<ref name="delta" /> Clinical diagnosis of Wernicke's disease cannot be made without evidence of ocular disturbance, yet these criteria may be too rigid.<ref name= juliet>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/jnnp.49.4.341 |title=Clinical signs in the Wernicke-Korsakoff complex: A retrospective analysis of 131 cases diagnosed at necropsy |year=1986 |last1=Harper |first1=C G |last2=Giles |first2=M |last3=Finlay-Jones |first3=R |journal=Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry |volume=49 |issue=4 |pages=341–5 |pmid=3701343 |pmc=1028756}}</ref> Korsakoff's likely represents a variation in the clinical manifestation of Wernicke encephalophathy, as they both share similar pathological origin.<ref name="juliet"/>
Korsakoff's syndrome is often characterized by [[confabulation]], disorientation, and profound [[amnesia]].<ref name="india"/> Characteristics of the neuropathology are varied, but generally consist of bilaterally symmetrical midline [[lesion]]s of [[brainstem]] areas, including the [[mammillary bodies]], [[thalamus]], [[Periaqueductal gray|periaqueductal region]], [[hypothalamus]], and the [[cerebellar vermis]].<ref name="hotel"/><ref name="india"/>
====Treatment==== Immediate treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy involves the administration of [[Intravenous therapy|intravenous]] thiamine, followed with long-term treatment and prevention of the disorder through oral thiamine supplements, alcohol [[abstinence]], and a balanced diet.<ref name="delta" /> Improvements in brain functioning of chronic alcoholics may occur with abstinence-related treatment, involving the discontinuation of alcohol consumption and improved nutrition.<ref name="hotel"/> Wernicke's encephalopathy is life-threatening if left untreated. However, a rapid reversal of symptoms may result from prompt administration of thiamine.<ref name="echo"/>
====Prevention==== [[Food fortification|Fortification]] of flour is practiced in some countries to replace the thiamine lost during processing. However, this method has been criticized for missing the target population of chronic alcoholics, who are most at risk for deficiency. Alternative solutions have suggested the fortification of alcoholic beverages with thiamine.<ref name="echo"/>
Ingesting a diet rich in thiamine may stave off the adverse effects of deficiency. Foods providing rich sources of thiamine include [[Whole foods|unrefined grain products]], ready-to-eat [[Breakfast cereal|cereals]], meat (especially pork), [[Dairy|dairy products]], peanuts, [[legume]]s, fruits and eggs.<ref>{{cite book |title=Vitamin Basics: The facts about Vitamins in Nutrition |year=2007 |publisher=DSM Nutritional Products Ltd. |location=Germany |isbn= |url=http://www.dsm.com/en_US/downloads/dnp/Vitamin_Basics.pdf |accessdate=2012}}{{page needed|was "|page=71 |pages=1–97". which is it?|date=July 2012}}</ref>
===Niacin (vitamin B3)=== Vitamin B<sub>3</sub>, also known as niacin, includes both [[nicotinamide]] as well as [[nicotinic acid]], both of which function in many [[Biological oxidizer|biological oxidization]] and reduction reactions within the body. These functions include the [[Biodegradation|biochemical degradation]] of carbohydrates, [[Lipid|fats]] and [[protein]]s. Niacin is also involved in the synthesis of [[fatty acids]] and [[cholesterol]],<ref name="kilo">{{cite book |title=Dietary Reference Intakes for Thiamin, Riboflavin, Niacin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Vitamin B12, Pantothenic Acid, Biotin, and Choline |year=1998 |publisher=National Academy Press |location=Washington, DC |isbn=0-309-06554-2 |url=http://www.nal.usda.gov/fnic/DRI/DRI_Thiamin/123-149_150.pdf |accessdate=2012}}{{page needed|was "|page=123 |pages=1–541". which is it?|date=July 2012}}</ref> which are known mediators of brain biochemistry, and in effect, of cognitive function.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-4547(19990615)56:6<565::AID-JNR2>3.0.CO;2-H |title=Essential fatty acids are mediators of brain biochemistry and cognitive functions |year=1999 |last1=Yehuda |first1=Shlomo |last2=Rabinovitz |first2=Sharon |last3=Mostofsky |first3=David I. |journal=Journal of Neuroscience Research |volume=56 |issue=6 |pages=565–70 |pmid=10374811}}</ref>
Sufficient niacin intake is either obtained from diet, or synthesized from the [[amino acid]] [[tryptophan]].<ref name="kilo"/>
====Deficiencies==== [[File:Pellagra2.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Pellagra initially presents as dermatitis]] Severe niacin deficiency typically manifests itself as the disease [[pellagra]].<ref name="kilo"/> Synthesis of B<sub>3</sub> from tryptophan involves [[Riboflavin|vitamin B<sub>2</sub>]] and B<sub>6</sub>, so deficiencies in either of these nutrients can lead to niacin deficiency. An excess of [[leucine]], an [[essential amino acid]], in the diet can also interfere with tryptophan conversion and subsequently result in a B<sub>3</sub> deficiency.<ref name= lima>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1365-4632.2004.01959.x |title=Pellagra: Dermatitis, dementia, and diarrhea |year=2004 |last1=Hegyi |first1=Juraj |last2=Schwartz |first2=Robert A. |last3=Hegyi |first3=Vladimir |journal=International Journal of Dermatology |volume=43 |pages=1–5 |pmid=14693013 |issue=1}}</ref>
Pellagra is most common to populations within developing countries in which [[corn]] is the dietary [[Staple food|staple]]. The disease has virtually disappeared from industrialized countries, yet still appears in India and parts of China and Africa.<ref name="kilo"/> This is in part due to the bound form of niacin that unprocessed corn contains, which is not readily absorbed into the human body. The processes involved in making corn [[tortillas]], can release the bound niacin into a more absorbable form. Pellagra is not problematic in countries which traditionally prepare their corn in this way, but is a problem in other countries where unprocessed corn is main source of caloric intake.<ref name= mike>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1017/S1041610205001961 |title=Metabolic and endocrinological causes of dementia |year=2005 |last1=Flicker |first1=Leon |last2=Ames |first2=David |journal=International Psychogeriatrics |volume=17 |pages=S79–92 |pmid=16240485}}</ref>
Though pellagra predominantly occurs in [[Developing country|developing countries]], sporadic cases of pellagra may be observed within industrialized nations, primarily in chronic alcoholics and patients living with functional absorption complications.<ref name="lima"/>
====Symptoms==== Pellagra is classically characterized by four 4 "D's": diarrhea, [[dermatitis]], dementia, and death.<ref name="lima"/> Neuropsychiatric manifestations of pellagra include headache, irritability, poor concentration, anxiety, hallucinations, stupor, apathy, psychomotor unrest, photophobia, tremor, ataxia, spastic paresis, fatigue, and depression. Symptoms of fatigue and insomnia may progress to encephalopathy characterized by confusion, memory loss, and psychosis.<ref name="lima"/>
Those afflicted with pellagra may undergo pathological alterations in the nervous system. Findings may include [[Myelin|demylenation]] and degeneration of various affected parts of the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral [[nerves]].<ref>{{Cite journal |pmid=21433862 |year=1939 |last1=Zimmerman |first1=HM |title=The Pathology of the Nervous System in Vitamin Deficiencies |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=23–28.7 |pmc=2602501 |journal=The Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine}}</ref>
====Treatment==== Prognosis of deficiency is excellent with treatment. Without, pellagra will gradually progress and lead to death within 4–5 years, often a result of [[malnutrition]] from prolonged diarrhea, or complications as caused by concurrent infections or neurological symptoms. Symptoms of pellagra can be cured with [[Exogeny|exogenous administration]] of nicotinic acid or nicotinamide.<ref name="lima"/>
[[Flushing (physiology)|Flushing]] occurs in many patients treated therapeutically with nicotinic acid,<ref name="kilo_page_b">{{cite book |title=Dietary Reference Intakes for Thiamin, Riboflavin, Niacin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Vitamin B12, Pantothenic Acid, Biotin, and Choline |year=1998 |publisher=National Academy Press |location=Washington, DC |isbn=0-309-06554-2 |url=http://www.nal.usda.gov/fnic/DRI/DRI_Thiamin/123-149_150.pdf |accessdate=2012}}{{page needed|was "|page=123 |pages=1–541". which is it?|date=July 2012}}</ref> and as a result, nicotinamide holds more clinical value as it is not associated with the same uncomfortable flushing. The adult dose of nicotinamide is 100 mg taken orally every 6 hours until resolution of major acute symptoms, followed with oral administration of 50 mg every 8–12 hours until skin lesions heal. For children, treatment involves oral ingestion of 10–15 mg of nicotinamide, depending on weight, every 6 hours until signs and symptoms are resolved. Severe cases require 1 gram every 3–4 hours, administered [[parenterally]].<ref name="lima"/>
Oral nicotinamide has been promoted as an over-the-counter drug for the treatment of [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer's dementia]]. Conversely, no clinically significant effect has been found for the drug, as nicotinamide administration has not been found to promote memory functions in patients with mild to moderate dementia of either Alzheimer's, vascular, or fronto-temporal types. This evidence suggests that nicotinamide may treat dementia as related to pellagra, but administration does not effectively treat other types of dementia.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1007/s007020070011 |title=No evidence for cognitive improvement from oral nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) in dementia |year=2000 |last1=Rainer |first1=M. |last2=Kraxberger |first2=E. |last3=Haushofer |first3=M. |last4=Mucke |first4=H. A. M. |last5=Jellinger |first5=K. A. |journal=Journal of Neural Transmission |volume=107 |issue=12 |pages=1475–81 |pmid=11459000}}</ref>
====Prevention==== The best method of prevention is to each food rich in B<sub>3</sub>. Generally, this involves the intake of a protein-rich diet. Foods that contain high concentrations of niacin in the free form include beans and organ meat, as well as enriched grain and cereal products.<ref name="kilo"/> While niacin is present in corn and other grains, the [[bioavailability]] of the nutrient is much less than it is in protein-rich sources. Different methods of processing corn may result in a higher degree of bioavailability of the vitamin.<ref name="mike"/>
Though treatment with niacin does little to alter the effects of Alzheimer's dementia, niacin intake from foods is inversely associated with the disease.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1136/jnnp.2003.025858 |title=Dietary niacin and the risk of incident Alzheimer's disease and of cognitive decline |year=2004 |last1=Morris |first1=M C |journal=Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry |volume=75 |issue=8 |pages=1093–1099}}</ref>
===Folate (vitamin B9)=== Folate deficiency can disrupt neurulation and neurogenesis. Maternal folic acid intake around the time of conception prevents neural tube defects.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Milunsky A. |author2=Jick H. |author3=Jick S. S. |author4=Bruell C. L. |author5=MacLaughlin D. S. |author6=Rothman K. J. |author7=Willett W. | year = 1989 | title = Multivitamin/folic acid supplementation in early pregnancy reduces the prevalence of neural tube defects | url = | journal = JAMA | volume = 262 | issue = 20| pages = 2847–2852 | doi=10.1001/jama.262.20.2847 | pmid=2478730}}</ref> Furthermore, folic acid intake was recently associated with incidence of autism.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Schmidt R. J. |author2=Tancredi D. J. |author3=Ozonoff S. |author4=Hansen R. L. |author5=Hartiala J. |author6=Allayee H. |author7=Hertz-Picciotto I. | year = 2012 | title = Maternal periconceptional folic acid intake and risk of autism spectrum disorders and developmental delay in the CHARGE (CHildhood Autism Risks from Genetics and Environment) case-control study | url = | journal = The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition | volume = 96 | issue = 1| pages = 80–89 | doi=10.3945/ajcn.110.004416 | pmid=22648721 | pmc=3374734}}</ref> Enriched white flour is fortified with folic acid in the United States and many other countries. However the European Union does not have mandatory folic acid fortification. Although the protective effects of folic acid are well documented, there remains legitimate concern that fortification could lead to toxic levels in a subset of the population. For example, elevated levels of folic acid can interact with vitamin B12 deficiency to cause neurodegeneration.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Blasko I. |author2=Hinterberger M. |author3=Kemmler G. |author4=Jungwirth S. |author5=Krampla W. |author6=Leitha T. |author7=Fischer P. | year = 2012 | title = Conversion from mild cognitive impairment to dementia: influence of folic acid and vitamin B12 use in the VITA cohort | url = | journal = The Journal of Nutrition, Health & Aging | volume = 16 | issue = 8| pages = 687–694 | doi=10.1007/s12603-012-0051-y}}</ref> Furthermore, folic acid and iron can interact to exacerbate malaria.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Titaley C. R. |author2=Dibley M. J. |author3=Roberts C. L. |author4=Agho K. | year = 2010 | title = Combined iron/folic acid supplements and malaria prophylaxis reduce neonatal mortality in 19 sub-Saharan African countries | url = | journal = The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition | volume = 92 | issue = 1| pages = 235–243 | doi=10.3945/ajcn.2009.29093 | pmid=20504976}}</ref>
Folic acid is the most oxidized and stable form of folate, and can also be referred to as vitamin B<sub>9</sub>. It rarely occurs naturally in foods, but it is the form used in vitamin supplements as well as fortified food products.<ref name="november">{{cite book |title=Dietary Reference Intakes for Thiamin, Riboflavin, Niacin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Vitamin B12, Pantothenic Acid, Biotin, and Choline |year=1998 |publisher=National Academy Press |location=Washington, DC |isbn=0-309-06554-2 |url=http://www.nal.usda.gov/fnic/DRI/DRI_Thiamin/196-305_150.pdf |accessdate=2012}}{{page needed|was "|page=196 |pages=1–541". which is it?|date=July 2012}}</ref>
Folate coenzymes are involved in numerous conversion processes within the body, including DNA synthesis and amino acid interconversions.<ref name="november"/> Folate and vitamin B<sub>12</sub> play a vital role in the synthesis of [[S-Adenosyl methionine|S-adenosylmethionine]], which is of key importance in the maintenance and repairment of all cells, including neurons.<ref name="oscar p230-5">{{cite journal |pmid=1865312 |year=1991 |last1=Hauck |first1=MR |title=Cognitive abilities of preschool children: Implications for nurses working with young children |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=230–5 |journal=Journal of Pediatric Nursing}}</ref> In addition, folate has been linked to the maintenance of adequate brain levels of cofactors necessary for chemicals reactions that lead to the synthesis of serotonin and catecholamine neurotransmitters.<ref name="november"/>
Folate has a major, but indirect role in activities which help to direct gene expression and [[Cell growth|cell proliferation]]. These activities occur at a greatly increased rate during [[pregnancy]], and depend on adequate levels of folate within [[blood plasma]].<ref name= papa>{{cite journal |pmid=11475447 |year=2001 |last1=Moyers |first1=S |last2=Bailey |first2=LB |title=Fetal malformations and folate metabolism: Review of recent evidence |volume=59 |issue=7 |pages=215–24 |journal=Nutrition Reviews |doi=10.1111/j.1753-4887.2001.tb07013.x}}</ref>
Concentrations of blood plasma folate and [[homocysteine]] concentrations are inversely related, such that an increase in dietary folate decreases homocysteine concentration. Thus, dietary intake of folate is a major determinant of homocysteine levels within the body.<ref name= quebec>{{Cite journal |pmid=16210710 |year=2005 |author1=Homocysteine Lowering Trialists' Collaboration |title=Dose-dependent effects of folic acid on blood concentrations of homocysteine: A meta-analysis of the randomized trials |volume=82 |issue=4 |pages=806–12 |journal=The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition}}</ref>
[[Autoantibodies]] against [[folate receptor alpha]] have been found in up to 75% of children with autism.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Frye|first=R. E.|last2=Sequeira|first2=J. M.|last3=Quadros|first3=E. V.|last4=James|first4=S. J.|last5=Rossignol|first5=D. A.|date=2013-03-01|title=Cerebral folate receptor autoantibodies in autism spectrum disorder|journal=Molecular Psychiatry|volume=18|issue=3|pages=369–381|doi=10.1038/mp.2011.175|pmc=3578948|pmid=22230883}}</ref>
====Deficiencies==== Folate deficiency most commonly arises from insufficient folate intake from the diet, but may also stem from inefficient absorption or metabolic utilization of folate, usually a result of genetic variation.<ref name= zulu>{{cite book |doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004514 |chapter=Folic acid with or without vitamin B12 for cognition and dementia |title=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews |year=2003 |last1=Malouf |first1=R|authorlink2=John Grimley Evans |last2=Grimley Evans |first2=J |last3=Areosa Sastre |first3=A |editor1-last=Malouf |editor1-first=Reem}}</ref> The relationship between folate and B<sub>12</sub> is so interdependent that deficiency in either vitamin can result in [[megaloblastic anemia]], characterized by organic mental change.<ref name= romeo>{{cite journal |pmid=9155210 |year=1996 |last1=Bottiglieri |first1=T |title=Folate, vitamin B12, and neuropsychiatric disorders |volume=54 |issue=12 |pages=382–90 |journal=Nutrition Reviews |doi=10.1111/j.1753-4887.1996.tb03851.x}}</ref>
The process of neural tube transformation into structures that will eventually develop into the central nervous system is known as [[neurulation]], the success of which is dependent on the presence of folate within the body. This process begins in the human approximately 21 days after [[fertilisation|conception]], and is completed by 28 days. Thus, a woman may not even be aware of her pregnancy by the time the process of neurulation is complete, potentially causing severe consequences in the development of the fetus.<ref name="november"/>
Functional problems in the absorption and utilization of vitamins may also play a role in folate deficiencies within the elderly.<ref name="oscar p230-5" />
====Symptoms==== [[File:Anencephaly side.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Anencephaly is the most common presentation of neural tube defects<ref name="dingus">{{Cite journal |doi=10.1056/NEJM199911113412006 |title=Neural-Tube Defects |year=1999 |last1=Botto |first1=Lorenzo D. |last2=Moore |first2=Cynthia A. |last3=Khoury |first3=Muin J. |last4=Erickson |first4=J.
