David |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=341 |issue=20 |pages=1509–19 |pmid=10559453}}</ref>]] The link between levels of folate and altered mental function is not large, but is sufficient enough to suggest a causal association.<ref name="november"/> Deficiency in folate can cause an elevation of homocysteine within the blood,<ref name="quebec"/> as the clearance of homocysteine requires enzymatic action dependent on folate, and to a lesser extent, vitamins B<sub>6</sub> and B<sub>12</sub>. Elevated homocysteine has been associated with increased risk of [[Stroke|vascular events]], as well as dementia.<ref>{{Cite journal |pmid=15213037 |year=2004 |last1=Quadri |first1=P |last2=Fragiacomo |first2=C |last3=Pezzati |first3=R |last4=Zanda |first4=E |last5=Forloni |first5=G |last6=Tettamanti |first6=M |last7=Lucca |first7=U |title=Homocysteine, folate, and vitamin B-12 in mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer disease, and vascular dementia |volume=80 |issue=1 |pages=114–22 |journal=The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition}}</ref>
Differences lie in the presentation of megaloblastic anemia induced by either folate or B<sub>12</sub> deficiency. Megaloblastic anemia related to deficiency in B<sub>12</sub> generally results in peripheral neuropathy, whereas folate-related anemia often results in affective, or mood disorders.<ref name="romeo"/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.281.6247.1036 |title=The neuropsychiatry of megaloblastic anaemia |year=1980 |last1=Shorvon |first1=S D |last2=Carney |first2=M W |last3=Chanarin |first3=I |last4=Reynolds |first4=E H |journal=BMJ |volume=281 |issue=6247 |pages=1036–8 |pmid=6253016 |pmc=1714413}}</ref> Neurological effects are not often associated with folate-related megaloblastic anemia, although demyelinating disorders may eventually present.<ref name="romeo"/> In one study, mood disturbances were recorded for the majority of patients presenting with megaloblastic anemia in the absence of B<sub>12</sub> deficiency.<ref name="november"/> In addition, folate concentrations within blood plasma have been found to be lower in patients with both unipolar and bipolar depressive disorders when compared with control groups. In addition, depressive groups with low folate concentrations responded less well to standard [[Antidepressant|antidepressant therapy]] than did those with normal levels within plasma.<ref name="november"/> However, replication of these findings are less robust.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=12042457 |year=2002 |last1=Bryan |first1=J |last2=Calvaresi |first2=E |last3=Hughes |first3=D |title=Short-term folate, vitamin B-12 or vitamin B-6 supplementation slightly affects memory performance but not mood in women of various ages |volume=132 |issue=6 |pages=1345–56 |journal=The Journal of Nutrition}}</ref>
The role of folic acid during pregnancy is vital to normal development of the nervous system in the fetus. A deficiency in folate levels of a pregnant woman could potentially result in [[Neural tube defects|neural tube disorder]], a debilitating condition in which the tubes of the central nervous system do not fuse entirely.<ref name="papa"/> NTDs are not to be confused with [[spina bifida]], which does not involve neural elements.<ref name="november"/> Neural tube defects can present in a number of ways as a result of the improper closure at various points of the neural tube. The clinical spectrum of the disorder includes [[encephalocele]], craniorachischisis, and [[anencephaly]]. In addition, these defects can also be classified as open, if neural tissue is exposed or covered only by membrane, or can be classified as closed, if the tissue is covered by normal skin.<ref name="dingus"/>
Intake of the vitamin has been linked to deficits in [[learning]] and memory, particularly within the elderly population.<ref name="november"/> Elderly people deficient in folate may present with deficits in free recall and recognition, which suggests that levels of folate may be related to efficacy of episodic memory.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0882-7974.11.3.487 |title=Effects of serum vitamin B-sub-1-sub-2 and folate status on episodic memory performance in very old age: A population-based study |year=1996 |last1=Wahlin |first1=Åke |last2=Hill |first2=Robert D. |last3=Winblad |first3=Bengt |last4=Bäckman |first4=Lars |journal=Psychology and Aging |volume=11 |issue=3 |pages=487–96 |pmid=8893317}}</ref>
====Treatment==== Lack of adequate folate may produce a form of dementia considered to be reversible with administration of the vitamin. Indeed, there is a degree of improvement in memory associated with folate treatment. In a 3-year longitudinal study of men and women aged 50–70 years with elevated homocysteine plasma concentration, researchers found that a daily oral folic acid supplementation of 800μg resulted in an increase in folate levels and a decrease in homocysteine levels within blood plasma. In addition to these results, improvements of memory, and information-processing speed, as well as slight improvements of [[Sensory-motor coupling|sensorimotor]] speed were observed,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(07)60109-3 |title=Effect of 3-year folic acid supplementation on cognitive function in older adults in the FACIT trial: A randomised, double blind, controlled trial |year=2007 |last1=Durga |first1=Jane |last2=Van Boxtel |first2=Martin PJ |last3=Schouten |first3=Evert G |last4=Kok |first4=Frans J |last5=Jolles |first5=Jelle |last6=Katan |first6=Martijn B |last7=Verhoef |first7=Petra |journal=The Lancet |volume=369 |issue=9557 |pages=208–216 |pmid=17240287}}</ref> which suggests there is a link between homocysteine and cognitive performance.
However, while the amount of cognitive improvement after treatment with folate is correlated with the severity of folate deficiency, the severity of cognitive decline is independent of the severity of folate deficiency. This suggests that the dementia observed may not be entirely related to levels of folate, as there could be additional factors that were not accounted for which might have an effect.<ref name="oscar p1-13">{{cite journal |pmid=18653121 |year=1998 |last1=Fioravanti |first1=M |last2=Ferrario |first2=E |last3=Massaia |first3=M |last4=Cappa |first4=G |last5=Rivolta |first5=G |last6=Grossi |first6=E |last7=Buckley |first7=AE |title=Low folate levels in the cognitive decline of elderly patients and the efficacy of folate as a treatment for improving memory deficits |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=1–13 |journal=Archives of Gerontology and Geriatrics |doi=10.1016/s0167-4943(97)00028-9}}</ref>
====Prevention==== Because neurulation may be completed before pregnancy is recognized, it is recommended that women capable of becoming pregnant take about 400μg of folic acid from fortified foods, supplements, or a combination of the two in order to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.<ref name="november"/> These major anomalies in the nervous system can be reduced by 85% with systematic folate supplementation occurring before the onset of pregnancy.<ref name="papa"/>
The incidence of Alzheimer's and other cognitive diseases has been loosely connected to deficiencies in folate. It is recommended for the elderly to consume folate through food, fortified or not, and supplements in order to reduce risk of developing the disease.<ref name="oscar p1-13"/> Good sources of folate include [[Liver (food)|liver]], ready-to-eat breakfast cereals, beans, asparagus, spinach, broccoli, and orange juice.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=2773830 |year=1989 |last1=Subar |first1=AF |last2=Block |first2=G |last3=James |first3=LD |title=Folate intake and food sources in the US population |volume=50 |issue=3 |pages=508–16 |journal=The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition}}</ref>
===Choline=== Choline is an important methyl donor involved in one-carbon metabolism that also becomes incorporated into phospholipids and the neurotransmitter acetylcholine. Because of its role in cellular synthesis, choline is an important nutrient during the prenatal and early postnatal development of offspring as it contributes heavily to the development of the brain. A study found that rats that were given supplements of choline in utero or in the weeks following birth had superior memories. The changes appeared to be a result of physical changes to the [[hippocampus]], the area of the brain responsible for memory.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=15640516 |year=2004 |last1=Zeisel |first1=SH |title=Nutritional importance of choline for brain development |volume=23 |issue=6 Suppl |pages=621S–626S |journal=Journal of the American College of Nutrition |doi=10.1080/07315724.2004.10719433}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Zeisel S. H. | year = 2006 | title = The fetal origins of memory: the role of dietary choline in optimal brain development | journal = The Journal of Pediatrics | volume = 149 | issue = 5| pages = S131–S136 | doi=10.1016/j.jpeds.2006.06.065 | pmid=17212955 | pmc=2430654}}</ref> Furthermore, choline can reduce some of the deleterious effects of folate deficiency on neurogenesis.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Craciunescu C. N. |author2=Johnson A. R. |author3=Zeisel S. H. | year = 2010 | title = Dietary choline reverses some, but not all, effects of folate deficiency on neurogenesis and apoptosis in fetal mouse brain | url = | journal = The Journal of Nutrition | volume = 140 | issue = 6| pages = 1162–1166 | doi=10.3945/jn.110.122044}}</ref>
While choline during development is important, adult levels of choline are also important. Choline has been shown to increase the synthesis and release of acetylcholine from neurons,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.6867732 |title=Choline and cholinergic neurons |year=1983 |last1=Blusztajn |first1=J. |last2=Wurtman |first2=R. |journal=Science |volume=221 |issue=4611 |pages=614–20 |pmid=6867732|bibcode=1983Sci...221..614B }}</ref> which in turn increases memory. A [[Blind experiment#Double-blind trials|double-blind study]] was conducted using normal college students (no neurological disorders). Results showed that twenty-five [[gram]]s of [[phosphatidylcholine]] (another form of choline) created a significant improvement in [[explicit memory]], measured by a [[Serial learning|serial learning task]], however this improvement may be attributed to the improvement of slow learners.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1097/00002826-199312000-00007 |title=Brief Report |year=1993 |last1=Ladd |first1=Sandra L. |last2=Sommer |first2=Susan A. |last3=Laberge |first3=Stephen |last4=Toscano |first4=William |journal=Clinical Neuropharmacology |volume=16 |issue=6 |pages=540–9 |pmid=9377589}}</ref> Another study found that a single ten-gram oral dose of choline, given to normal volunteers (again, without neurological disorders) significantly decreased the number of trials needed to master a serial-learning word test. This increase in memory is particularly beneficial to memory loss suffered by old age. A study conducted on rats who, like humans, suffer from an age-related loss of memory were tested on how choline affected memory. The results showed that rats who had a chronic low-choline diet showed greater memory loss then their same-age control counterparts, while rats who had choline-enriched diets showed a diminished memory loss compared to both the choline-low diet and control rat groups. Furthermore, young rats who were choline-deficient performed as poorly on memory tasks as older rats while older rats that were given choline supplements performed as well as three-month-old rats.<ref name="Zeisel SH">{{cite journal |doi=10.1146/annurev.nutr.26.061505.111156 |title=Choline: Critical Role During Fetal Development and Dietary Requirements in Adults |year=2006 |last1=Zeisel |first1=Steven H. |journal=Annual Review of Nutrition |volume=26 |pages=229–50 |pmid=16848706 |pmc=2441939}}</ref>
====Deficiencies and treatments==== Despite the wide range of foods that choline is found in, studies have shown that the mean choline intake of men, women and children are below the [[Adequate Intake]] levels.<ref name="Zeisel SH, da Costa KA">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1753-4887.2009.00246.x |title=Choline: An essential nutrient for public health |year=2009 |last1=Zeisel |first1=Steven H |last2=Da Costa |first2=Kerry-Ann |journal=Nutrition Reviews |volume=67 |issue=11 |pages=615–23 |pmid=19906248 |pmc=2782876}}</ref> It is important to note that not enough choline is naturally produced by the body, so diet is an important factor. People who consume a large quantity of alcohol may be at an increased risk for choline deficiency. [[Sex]] and age also plays a role, with [[Premenopause|premenopausal]] females being less sensitive to choline deficiency than either males or [[Postmenopause|postmenopausal]] females.<ref name="Zeisel SH"/> This has been theorized to be a result of premenopausal women having an increased ability to synthesize choline in some form, which has been confirmed in studies on rats.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1074/jbc.M301982200 |title=A Gender-specific Role for Phosphatidylethanolamine N-Methyltransferase-derived Phosphatidylcholine in the Regulation of Plasma High Density and Very Low Density Lipoproteins in Mice |year=2003 |last1=Noga |first1=A. A. |journal=Journal of Biological Chemistry |volume=278 |issue=24 |pages=21851–9 |pmid=12668679 |last2=Vance |first2=DE}}</ref> In such instances of deficiency, choline supplements or (if able) dietary changes may be beneficial. Good sources of choline include liver, milk, eggs and peanuts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iom.edu/Activities/Nutrition/SummaryDRIs/~/media/Files/Activity%20Files/Nutrition/DRIs/DRI_Vitamins.ashx |title=Dietary Reference Intakes |publisher=[[Institute of Medicine]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100419072548/http://www.iom.edu/Activities/Nutrition/SummaryDRIs/~/media/Files/Activity%20Files/Nutrition/DRIs/DRI_Vitamins.ashx |archivedate=19 April 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> There is further evidence to suggest that choline supplements can be used to treat people who suffer from neurological disorders as well we memory defects.<ref name="Zeisel SH"/><ref name="Zeisel SH, da Costa KA"/> Oral doses of [[CDP-choline]] (another form of choline) given to [[Old age|elderly]] subjects with memory deficits, but without dementia, for four weeks showed improved memory in free recall tasks, but not in recognition tests.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=9203170 |year=1997 |last1=Alvarez |first1=XA |last2=Laredo |first2=M |last3=Corzo |first3=D |last4=Fernández-Novoa |first4=L |last5=Mouzo |first5=R |last6=Perea |first6=JE |last7=Daniele |first7=D |last8=Cacabelos |first8=R |title=Citicoline improves memory performance in elderly subjects |volume=19 |issue=3 |pages=201–10 |journal=Methods and Findings in Experimental and Clinical Pharmacology}}</ref> In a second study, patients with early Alzheimer-type dementia were treated with twenty-give gram doses of phosphatidylcholine every day for six months. Slightly improvements were shown in memory tests compared to the placebo control group. It should be noted however that other studies conducted did not find any such improvement.
===Cobalamin (vitamin B12)=== Also known as cobalamin, B<sub>12</sub> is an essential vitamin necessary for normal [[Hematopoiesis|blood formation]]. It is also important for the maintenance of neurological function and psychiatric health.<ref name= sierra>{{cite book |title=Dietary Reference Intakes for Thiamin, Riboflavin, Niacin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Vitamin B12, Pantothenic Acid, Biotin, and Choline |year=1998 |publisher=National Academy Press |location=Washington, DC |isbn=0-309-06554-2 |url=http://www.nal.usda.gov/fnic/DRI/DRI_Thiamin/306-356_150.pdf |accessdate=2012}}{{page needed|was "|page=306 |pages=1–541". which is it?|date=July 2012}}</ref> The absorption of B<sub>12</sub> into the body requires adequate amounts of [[intrinsic factor]], the [[glycoprotein]] produced in the [[parietal cells]] of the stomach lining. A functioning [[small intestine]] is also necessary for the proper metabolism of the vitamin, as absorption occurs within the [[ileum]].<ref name="sierra"/>
B<sub>12</sub> is produced in the digestive tracts of all animals, including humans.<ref name= tango>{{cite book |title=Vitamin Basics: The facts about Vitamins in Nutrition |year=2007 |publisher=DSM Nutritional Products |url=http://www.dsm.com/en_US/downloads/dnp/Vitamin_Basics.pdf |accessdate=2012}}{{page needed|was "|page=65 |pages=1–97". which is it?|date=July 2012}}</ref> Thus, animal-origin food is the only natural food source of vitamin B<sub>12</sub><ref name= uniform>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1146/annurev.nutr.19.1.357 |title=Vitamin B12 Deficiency in the Elderly |year=1999 |last1=Baik |first1=H.W. |last2=Russell |first2=R.M. |journal=Annual Review of Nutrition |volume=19 |pages=357–77 |pmid=10448529}}</ref> However, synthesis of B<sub>12</sub> occurs in the [[large intestine]], which is past the point of absorption that occurs within the small intestine. As such, vitamin B<sub>12</sub> must be obtained through diet.<ref name="tango"/>
====Deficiencies==== Unlike other B vitamins which are not stored in the body, B<sub>12</sub> is stored in the [[liver]]. Because of this, it may take 5–10 years before a sudden dietary B<sub>12</sub> deficiency will become apparent in a previously healthy adult.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1046/j.1365-2036.1999.00616.x |title=Atrophic gastritis during long-term omeprazole therapy affects serum vitamin B12 levels |year=1999 |last1=Schenk |last2=Kuipers |last3=Klinkenberg-Knol |last4=Bloemena |last5=Sandell |last6=Nelis |last7=Snel |last8=Festen |last9=Meuwissen |journal=Alimentary Pharmacology and Therapeutics |volume=13 |issue=10 |pages=1343–6 |pmid=10540050 |first1=BE |first2=EJ |first3=EC |first4=EC |first5=M |first6=GF |first7=P |first8=HP |first9=SG }}</ref> B<sub>12</sub> deficiency, also known as hypocobalaminemia, often results from complications involving absorption into the body.<ref name= victor>{{Cite journal |pmid=17043022 |year=2006 |last1=Hvas |first1=AM |last2=Nexo |first2=E |title=Diagnosis and treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency--an update |volume=91 |issue=11 |pages=1506–12 |journal=Haematologica}}</ref>
B<sub>12</sub> deficiency is often associated with [[pernicious anemia]], as it is the most common cause. Pernicious anemia results from an [[Autoimmune disease|autoimmune disorder]] which destroys the cells that produce [[intrinsic factor]] within the stomach lining, thereby hindering B<sub>12</sub> absorption. B<sub>12</sub> absorption is important for the subsequent absorption of iron, thus, people with pernicious anemia often present with typical symptoms of [[anemia]], such as pale skin, dizziness, and fatigue.<ref name= whiskey>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1056/NEJM199711133372007 |title=Pernicious Anemia |year=1997 |last1=Epstein |first1=Franklin H. |last2=Toh |first2=Ban-Hock |last3=Van Driel |first3=Ian R. |last4=Gleeson |first4=Paul A. |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=337 |issue=20 |pages=1441–8 |pmid=9358143}}</ref>
Among those at highest risk for B<sub>12</sub> deficiency are the elderly population, as 10-15% of people aged 60+ may present with some form of hypocobalaminemia. High rates of deficiency in the elderly commonly results from the decrease of functional absorption of B<sub>12</sub>, as production of intrinsic factor declines with age. However, pernicious anemia is the most common cause of B<sub>12</sub> deficiency in North American and European populations.<ref name="uniform"/>
Those afflicted with various [[Digestive disease|gastrointestinal diseases]] may also be at risk for deficiency as a result of malabsorption. These diseases may affect production of intrinsic factor in the stomach, or of pancreatic [[bile]]. Diseases that involve disorders of the small intestine, such as celiac disease, [[Crohn's disease]] and [[ileitis]], may also reduce B<sub>12</sub> absorption. For example, people with celiac disease may damage the microvilli within their small intestines through the consumption of gluten, thereby inhibiting absorption of B<sub>12</sub> as well as other nutrients.<ref name="victor"/>
A diet low in B<sub>12</sub>, whether voluntary or not, can also cause symptoms of hypocobalaminemia. Many rich sources of B<sub>12</sub> come from animal meats and by-products. Populations in developing countries may not have access to these foods on a consistent basis, and as a result may become deficient in B<sub>12</sub>.<ref name= xray>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1146/annurev.nutr.24.012003.132440 |title=Vitamin B12 Deficiency As a Worldwide Problem |year=2004 |last1=Stabler |first1=Sally P. |last2=Allen |first2=Robert H. |journal=Annual Review of Nutrition |volume=24 |pages=299–326 |pmid=15189123}}</ref> In addition, [[Veganism|vegans]], and to a lesser extent [[Ovo-lacto vegetarianism|vegetarians]], are at risk for consuming a diet low in cobalamin as they voluntarily abstain from animal sources of B<sub>12</sub>.<ref name="victor"/> A combination of these two scenarios may increase prevalence of cobalamin deficit. For instance, B<sub>12</sub> deficiency is problematic in India, where the majority of the population is vegetarian and the scarcity of meat consumption is common for omnivores as well.<ref name="xray"/>
====Symptoms==== An assortment of neurological effects can be observed in 75-90% of individuals of any age with clinically observable B<sub>12</sub> deficiency. Cobalamin deficiency manifestations are apparent in the abnormalities of the spinal cord, peripheral nerves, optic nerves, and [[cerebrum]]. These abnormalities involve a progressive degeneration of [[myelin]],<ref name= yankee>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.2.5006.1394 |title=Cerebral Manifestations of Vitamin-B12 Deficiency |year=1956 |last1=Holmes |first1=J. M. |journal=BMJ |volume=2 |issue=5006 |pages=1394–8 |pmid=13374343 |pmc=2035923}}</ref> and may be expressed behaviourally through reports of sensory disturbances in the extremities, or motor disturbances, such as gait ataxia. Combined myelopathy and neuropathy are prevalent within a large percentage of cases. Cognitive changes may range from loss of concentration to memory loss, disorientation, and dementia. All of these symptoms may present with or without additional mood changes.<ref name="uniform"/> Mental symptoms are extremely variable, and include mild disorders of mood, mental slowness, and memory defect. Memory defect encompasses symptoms of [[Mental confusion|confusion]], severe agitation and depression, [[delusions]] and paranoid behaviour, visual and auditory [[hallucinations]], [[urinary incontinence|urinary]] and [[fecal incontinence]] in the absence of overt spinal lesions, dysphasia, violent maniacal behaviour, and epilepsy. It has been suggested that mental symptoms could be related to a decrease in cerebral metabolism, as caused by the state of deficiency.<ref name="yankee"/> All of these symptoms may present with or without additional mood changes.<ref name="uniform"/>
Mild to moderate cases of pernicious anemia may show symptoms of bleeding [[gums]], [[headache]], poor [[Attentional control|concentration]], shortness of breath, and weakness. In severe cases of pernicious anemia, individuals may present with various cognitive problems such as dementia, and memory loss.<ref name="whiskey"/>
It is not always easy to determine whether B<sub>12</sub> deficiency is present, especially within older adults.<ref name="victor"/> Patients may present with violent behaviour or more subtle personality changes. They may also present with vague complaints, such as fatigue or memory loss, that may be attributed to normative aging processes. Cognitive symptoms may mimic behaviour in Alzheimer's and other dementias as well.<ref name="uniform"/> Tests must be run on individuals presenting with such signs to confirm or negate cobalamin deficiency within the blood.<ref name="whiskey"/>
====Treatment==== [[File:B vitamin supplement tablets.jpg|240px|thumb|left|Individuals with absorption disorders, or those who abstain from animal products should supplement their diet with B<sub>12</sub> regularly]] Patients deficient in B<sub>12</sub> despite normal absorption functionality may be treated through oral administration of at least 6 mg of the vitamin in pill form. Patients who suffer from irreversible causes of deficiency, such as pernicious anemia or old age, will need lifelong treatment with pharmacological doses of B<sub>12</sub>. Strategy for treatment is dependent on the patient's level of deficiency as well as their level of cognitive functioning.<ref name="victor"/> Treatment for those with severe deficiency involves 1000 mg of B<sub>12</sub> administered [[Intramuscular injection|intramuscularly]] daily for one week, weekly for one month, then monthly for the rest of the patient's life. Daily oral supplementation of B<sub>12</sub> mega-doses may be sufficient in reliable patients, but it is imperative that the supplementation be continued on a lifelong basis as relapse may occur otherwise.<ref name="whiskey"/>
The progression of neurological manifestations of cobalamin deficiency is generally gradual. As a result, early diagnosis is important or else irreversible damage may occur.<ref name="sierra"/> Patients who become demented usually show little to no cognitive improvement with the administration of B<sub>12</sub>.<ref name="whiskey"/>
A deficiency in folate may produce anemia similar to the anemia resulting from B<sub>12</sub> deficiency. There is risk that folic acid administered to those with B<sub>12</sub> deficiency may mask anemic symptoms without solving the issue at hand. In this case, patients would still be at risk for neurological deficits associated with B<sub>12</sub> deficiency-related anemia, which are not associated with anemia related to folate deficiency.<ref name="zulu"/>
====Prevention==== In addition to meeting intake requirements through food consumption, supplementation of diet with vitamin B<sub>12</sub> is seen as a viable preventative measure for deficiency. It has been recommended for the elderly to supplement 50 mcg a day in order to prevent deficit from occurring.<ref name="whiskey"/>
Animal protein products are a good source of B<sub>12</sub>, particularly organ meats such as [[Kidney (food)|kidney]] or liver. Other good sources are fish, eggs, and dairy products.<ref name="tango"/> It is suggested that vegans, who consume no animal meat or by-products, supplement their diet with B<sub>12</sub>. While there are foods fortified with B<sub>12</sub> available, some may be mislabelled in an attempt to boost their nutritional claims. Products of fermentation, such as algae extracts and sea vegetables, may be labelled as sources of B<sub>12</sub>, but actually contain B<sub>12</sub> [[Structural analog|analogues]] which compete for the absorption of the nutrient itself.<ref name="xray" /> In order to get adequate amounts of the vitamin, orally administered pills or fortified foods such as cereals and soy milk, are recommended for vegans.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1079/BJN19780089 |title=Haematological studies on vegans |year=2007 |last1=Sanders |first1=T. A. B. |last2=Ellis |first2=F. R. |last3=Dickerson |first3=J. W. T. |journal=British Journal of Nutrition |volume=40 |pages=9–15 |pmid=667007 |issue=1}}</ref>
===Vitamin D=== Vitamin D is an essential regulator of the vitamin D receptor that controls gene transcription during development. The vitamin D receptor is strongly expressed in the substantia nigra.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Eyles D. W. |author2=Smith S. |author3=Kinobe R. |author4=Hewison M. |author5=McGrath J. J. | year = 2005 | title = Distribution of the vitamin D receptor and 1α-hydroxylase in human brain | url = | journal = Journal of Chemical Neuroanatomy | volume = 29 | issue = 1| pages = 21–30 | doi=10.1016/j.jchemneu.2004.08.006|pmid=15589699 }}</ref> Accordingly, vitamin D deficiency can disrupt neurogenesis leading to altered dopamine signaling and increased exploratory behavior in rats.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Kesby J. P., Cui X., O'Loan J., McGrath J. J., Burne T. H., Eyles D. W. | year = 2010 | title = Developmental vitamin D deficiency alters dopamine-mediated behaviors and dopamine transporter function in adult female rats | url = | journal = Psychopharmacology | volume = 208 | issue = 1| pages = 159–168 | pmid = 19921153 | last2 = Cui | last3 = O'Loan | last4 = McGrath | last5 = Burne | last6 = Eyles | doi = 10.1007/s00213-009-1717-y }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Kesby J. P. |author2=Burne T. H. |author3=McGrath J. J. |author4=Eyles D. W. | year = 2006 | title = Developmental vitamin D deficiency alters MK 801-induced hyperlocomotion in the adult rat: An animal model of schizophrenia | url = | journal = Biological Psychiatry | volume = 60 | issue = 6| pages = 591–596 | doi=10.1016/j.biopsych.2006.02.033 | pmid=16697353}}</ref> This is considered a rodent model of the schizophrenia phenotype and vitamin D deficiency has been proposed as an explanation for the increased incidence of schizophrenia among children that were conceived during winter months. A Finnish study found that vitamin D supplement use is associated with reduced risk of schizophrenia.<ref>{{cite journal | author = McGrath J., Saari K., Hakko H., Jokelainen J., Jones P., Järvelin M. R., Isohanni M. | year = 2004 | title = Vitamin D supplementation during the first year of life and risk of schizophrenia: a Finnish birth cohort study | url = | journal = Schizophrenia Research | volume = 67 | issue = 2| pages = 237–245 | doi=10.1016/j.schres.2003.08.005 | pmid=14984883| last2 = Saari | last3 = Hakko | last4 = Jokelainen | last5 = Jones | last6 = Järvelin | last7 = Chant | last8 = Isohanni }}</ref>
==Lipids== ===Fat=== Fatty acids are necessary for the synthesis of cell membranes neurotransmitters and other signaling molecules. While excessive fat intake can be harmful, deficiency of essential fatty acids can disrupt neurodevelopment and synaptic plasticity.<ref name="Lafourcade, M. 2011">{{cite journal |author1=Lafourcade M. |author2=Larrieu T. |author3=Mato S. |author4=Duffaud A. |author5=Sepers M. |author6=Matias I. |author7=Manzoni O. J. | year = 2011 | title = Nutritional omega-3 deficiency abolishes endocannabinoid-mediated neuronal functions | url = | journal = Nature Neuroscience | volume = 14 | issue = 3| pages = 345–350 | doi=10.1038/nn.2736 | pmid=21278728}}</ref>
====Saturated fat==== Consuming large amounts of saturated fat can negatively affect the brain. Eating foods with saturated fats elevates the level of cholesterol and triglycerides in the body. Studies have shown that high levels of triglycerides strongly link with mood problems such as depression, hostility and aggression. This may occur because high triglyceride levels decrease the amount of oxygen that blood can carry to the brain.<ref name="psych">{{cite journal|last=Blaun|first=Randy|author2=Andreas Wiesenack |title=How to Eat Smart|journal=Psychology Today|year=1996|volume=29|issue=3|pages=34|url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/articles/200301/brain-power-why-proteins-are-smart|accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> The American Heart Association recommends that people consume no more than 16g of saturated fat daily. Common sources of saturated fat are meat and dairy products.
====Essential fatty acids==== There are two kinds of essential fatty acids that people must consume (omega-3 and omega-6). Many academics recommend a balanced amount of omega-3s and omega-6s. However, some estimate that Americans consume twenty times more omega-6s than omega-3s. There is a theory that an imbalance of essential fatty acids may lead to mental disorders such as depression, hyperactivity and schizophrenia, but it still lacking evidences. An omega-3 deficient diet increases omega-6 levels in the brain disrupting endocannabinoid signaling in the prefrontal cortex and nucleus accumbens contributing to anxiety and depression-like behaviors in mice.<ref name="Lafourcade, M. 2011"/> [[Omega-3 fatty acid#Dietary sources|Sources of omega-3]] include flax seeds, chia seeds, walnuts, sea vegetables, green leafy vegetables, and cold water fish. Sources of omega-6 include walnuts, hazelnuts; sunflower, safflower, corn, and sesame oils.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Human Brain-Fats|url=http://www.fi.edu/learn/brain/fats.html|work=The Franklin Institute Online|accessdate=12 April 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526131629/http://www.fi.edu/learn/brain/fats.html#|archive-date=26 May 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Cholesterol=== While cholesterol is essential for membranes and steroid hormones, excess cholesterol affects blood flow impairing cognitive function in vascular dementia.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Moser D. J. |author2=Boles Ponto L. L. |author3=Miller I. N. |author4=Schultz S. K. |author5=Menda Y. |author6=Arndt S. |author7=Nopoulos P. C. | year = 2012 | title = Cerebral blood flow and neuropsychological functioning in elderly vascular disease patients | url = | journal = Journal of Clinical and Experimental Neuropsychology | volume = 34 | issue = 2| pages = 220–225 | doi=10.1080/13803395.2011.630653}}</ref>
==Carbohydrates== Studies have shown that learning and memory improve after consuming carbohydrates. There are two kinds of carbohydrates people consume: simple and complex. Simple carbohydrates are often found in processed foods and release sugar into the bloodstream quickly after consumption. Complex carbohydrates are digested more slowly and therefore cause sugar to be released into the bloodstream more slowly.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Human Brain-Carbohydrates|url=http://www.fi.edu/learn/brain/carbs.html|work=The Franklin Institute Online|accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> Good sources of complex carbohydrates are whole-grain breads, pasta, brown rice, oatmeal, and potatoes. It is recommended that people consume more complex carbohydrates because consuming complex carbohydrates will cause the level of sugar in the bloodstream to be more stable, which will cause less stress hormones to be released. Consuming simple carbohydrates may cause the levels of sugar in the bloodstream to rise and fall, which can cause mood swings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brain Foods|url=http://www.askdrsears.com/html/4/t040400.asp|work=Dr. Sears Official Website|accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
===Low carbohydrate ketogenic diets=== The ketone body beta-hydroxybutyrate is a fuel source for the brain during times of fasting when blood glucose levels fall. Although the mechanism is not understood, it is well established that eating a diet low in carbohydrates can be therapeutic for children with epilepsy.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Neal E. G. |author2=Chaffe H. |author3=Schwartz R. H. |author4=Lawson M. S. |author5=Edwards N. |author6=Fitzsimmons G. |author7=Cross J. H. | year = 2008 | title = The ketogenic diet for the treatment of childhood epilepsy: a randomised controlled trial | url = | journal = The Lancet Neurology | volume = 7 | issue = 6| pages = 500–506 | doi=10.1016/s1474-4422(08)70092-9 | pmid=18456557}}</ref> This is likely a result of ketone bodies providing an alternative fuel source to glucose for neuronal function. Furthermore, a ketogenic diet can be beneficial for dementia patients.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Henderson S. T. | year = 2008 | title = Ketone bodies as a therapeutic for Alzheimer's disease | url = | journal = Neurotherapeutics | volume = 5 | issue = 3| pages = 470–480 | doi=10.1016/j.nurt.2008.05.004}}</ref> [[Medium-chain triglyceride]]s can stimulate ketone synthesis<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Yeh Y. Y. |author2=Zee P. | year = 1976 | title = Relation of ketosis to metabolic changes induced by acute medium-chain triglyceride feeding in rats | url = | journal = The Journal of Nutrition | volume = 106 | issue = 1| page = 58 }}</ref> and coconut oil is a rich source of medium chain triglycerides that several anecdotal reports suggest can improve cognitive function in Alzheimer's type dementia patients.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abcactionnews.com/dpp/news/health/local-doctor-says-coconut-oil-helps-reduce-symptoms-of-alzheimers-disease|title=Local doctor says coconut oil helps reduce symptoms of Alzheimer's disease|first=Linda|last=Hurtado|date=5 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/health/spring-hill-couple-inspires-research-into-coconut-oil-for-alzheimers/2124596|title=Spring Hill couple inspires research into coconut oil for Alzheimer's patients|date=3 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
==Protein== When protein is consumed, it is broken down into amino acids. These amino acids are used to produce many things like neurotransmitters, enzymes, hormones, and chromosomes. Proteins known as complete proteins contain all eight of the essential amino acids. Meat, cheese, eggs, and yogurt are all examples of complete proteins. Incomplete proteins contain only some of the eight essential amino acids and it is recommended that people consume a combination of these proteins. Examples of incomplete proteins include nuts, seeds, legumes, and grains.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Human Brain-Protein|url=http://www.fi.edu/learn/brain/proteins.html|work=The Franklin Institute Online|accessdate=13 April 2011}}</ref> When animals are fed a diet deficient in essential amino acids, uncharged tRNAs accumulate in the anterior piriform cortex signaling diet rejection [105]. The body normally interconverts amino acids to maintain homeostasis, but muscle protein can be catabolized to release amino acids during conditions of amino acid deficiency. Disruption of amino acid metabolism can affect brain development and neurophysiology to affect behavior. For example, fetal protein deficiency decreases the number of neurons in the CA1 region of the hippocampus.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Lister J. P., Blatt G. J., DeBassio W. A., Kemper T. L., Tonkiss J., Galler J. R., Rosene D. L. | year = 2005 | title = Effect of prenatal protein malnutrition on numbers of neurons in the principal cell layers of the adult rat hippocampal formation | url = | journal = Hippocampus | volume = 15 | issue = 3| pages = 393–403 | doi=10.1002/hipo.20065 | pmid=15669101| last2 = Blatt | last3 = Debassio | last4 = Kemper | last5 = Tonkiss | last6 = Galler | last7 = Rosene }}</ref>
===Glutamate=== [[Glutamate]] is a [[proteinogenic amino acid]] and neurotransmitter, though it is perhaps publicly best known in its [[sodium]] [[salt]] form: [[monosodium glutamate]] (MSG). It is also a [[Glutamic acid (flavor)|flavor]] on its own, producing the [[umami]] or savory flavor found in many [[fermentation (food)|fermented]] foods such as [[cheese]]. As an amino acid it acts as a source of fuel for various cellular functions and as a neurotransmitter. Glutamate operates as an [[Neurotransmitter#Excitatory and inhibitory|excitatory neurotransmitter]] and is released when a nerve impulse excites a glutamate producing cell. This in turn binds to neurons with glutamate receptors, stimulating them.
====Deficiencies and treatments==== Glutamate is a nutrient that is extremely difficult to be deficient in, as, being an amino acid, it is found in every food that contains protein. Additionally it is found, as previously mentioned, in fermented foods and in foods containing monosodium glutamate. As such, good sources of glutamate include meat, fish, dairy products and a [[Glutamic acid (flavor)#Concentration in foods|wide array]] of other foods. Glutamate is also absorbed extremely efficiently by the intestines.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Peter J. |last1=Reeds |first2=Douglas G. |last2=Burrin |first3=Barbara |last3=Stoll |first4=Farook |last4=Jahoor |title=Intestinal Glutamate Metabolism |journal=The Journal of Nutrition |pmid=10736365 |url=http://jn.nutrition.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=10736365 |year=2000 |volume=130 |issue=4S Suppl |pages=978S–82S}}</ref> However, there are instances of glutamate deficiency occurring, but only in cases where genetic disorders are present. One such example is ''Glutamate formiminotransferase deficiency'' and can cause either minor or profound physical and intellectual disabilities, depending on the severity of the condition. This disorder is extremely rare however, as only twenty people have so far been identified with this condition.<ref>http://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/glutamate-formiminotransferase-deficiency{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref> Glutamate, while critically important in the body also acts as an [[Excitotoxicity|excitotoxin]] in high concentrations not normally found outside of laboratory conditions,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0896-6273(95)90186-8 |title=Glutamate-induced neuronal death: A succession of necrosis or apoptosis depending on mitochondrial function |year=1995 |last1=Ankarcrona |first1=Maria |last2=Dypbukt |first2=Jeannette M. |last3=Bonfoco |first3=Emanuela |last4=Zhivotovsky |first4=Boris |last5=Orrenius |first5=Sten |last6=Lipton |first6=Stuart A. |last7=Nicotera |first7=Pierluigi |journal=Neuron |volume=15 |issue=4 |pages=961–73 |pmid=7576644}}</ref> although it can occur following [[brain injury]] or [[spinal cord injury]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.brainresrev.2008.12.010 |title=Mechanisms of chronic central neuropathic ''pain after'' spinal cord injury |year=2009 |last1=Hulsebosch |first1=Claire E. |last2=Hains |first2=Bryan C. |last3=Crown |first3=Eric D. |last4=Carlton |first4=Susan M. |journal=Brain Research Reviews |volume=60 |pages=202–13 |pmid=19154757 |issue=1 |pmc=2796975}}</ref>
===Phenylalanine=== L-Phenylalanine is biologically converted into L-tyrosine, another one of the DNA-encoded amino acids, and beta-[[phenethylamine]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Broadley|first=KJ|title=The vascular effects of trace amines and amphetamines.|journal=Pharmacology & Therapeutics|date=March 2010|volume=125|issue=3|pages=363–75|pmid=19948186|doi=10.1016/j.pharmthera.2009.11.005}}</ref> L-tyrosine in turn is converted into L-DOPA, which is further converted into dopamine, norepinephrine (noradrenaline), and epinephrine (adrenaline). The latter three are known as the catecholamines. Phenethylamine is further converted into N-methylphenethylamine.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pendleton|first=RG|author2=Gessner, G |author3=Sawyer, J |title=Studies on lung N-methyltransferases, a pharmacological approach.|journal=Naunyn-Schmiedeberg's Archives of Pharmacology|date=September 1980|volume=313|issue=3|pages=263–8|pmid=7432557|doi=10.1007/BF00505743}}</ref> Phenylalanine uses the same active transport channel as tryptophan to cross the blood–brain barrier, and, in large quantities, interferes with the production of serotonin.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Pascucci T., Ventura R., Puglisi-Allegra S., Cabib S. | year = 2002 | title = Deficits in brain serotonin synthesis in a genetic mouse model of phenylketonuria | url = | journal = NeuroReport | volume = 13 | issue = 18| pages = 2561–2564 | pmid = 12499868 | last2 = Ventura | last3 = Puglisi-Allegra | last4 = Cabib | doi = 10.1097/00001756-200212200-00036}}</ref>
====Phenylketonuria==== Toxic levels of phenylalanine accumulate in the brains of patients with [[phenylketonuria]] leading to severe brain damage and mental retardation. To prevent brain damage, these individuals can restrict dietary phenylalanine intake by avoiding protein and supplementing their diet with essential amino acids.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Thompson A. J., Tillotson S., Smith I., Kendall B., Moore S. G., Brenton D. P. | year = 1993 | title = Brain MRI changes in phenylketonuria: associations with dietary status | url = | journal = Brain | volume = 116 | issue = 4| pages = 811–821 | doi=10.1093/brain/116.4.811| last2 = Tillotson | last3 = Smith | last4 = Kendall | last5 = Moore | last6 = Brenton }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Nutrition and cognition]] * [[Orthomolecular psychiatry]]
